description:
Dined here again and the food is still good and consistent.   They accept credit cards for payment.

SERVICE:  5/5
The nice male server was working.  When we walked in, he greeted us with a smile.  While we were dining at the restaurant, he was cordial, smiled and didn't hesitate to provide us service.  

We would definitely return to eat here again.

FOOD:  
 - Tomato Beef Chow Mein $8.00 - 5/5  
We always order this.  As a matter of fact, we got another one to go too.  We noticed again that the dine in order looks different than the take out order.  Maybe they have two different people cooking the food.  We ate the takeout at home and the flavors were totally different.  It didn't have enough tomato sauce flavor.  Dine-in one taste much better.

 - BBQ Pork chicken Fried Silver Noodle $7.50 - 5/5
Thin rice noodle fried with bbq pork, chicken and onions.  Very tasty.  Good wok heat flavor.  

 - Beef Chow Fun with Gravy $8.00 - 4/5
The taste is still the same as last time which the gravy was a little salty.   I usually order this because I can't cook the same flavor at home.  Next time, I would ask them to don't make the sauce so salty.
author: J W.

description:
My dad made a phone call to this restaurant last night to order 4 dishes for pick up. The lady on the phone was rushing and talking very fast as my dad was reading from a paper take out menu that we got from them many years ago. We picked up the order and brought it back home within 30 minutes.

Filet of Cod with Corn - delicious fish, with a slightly crispy bite to it and nice corn sauce over it

Beef with Black Bean Sauce Chow Fun - we got the wet style, and it's very delicious. Some restaurants give too much noodles and not enough meat. This place gave the perfect ratio of noodles, beef, and bell peppers/onions.

Roast Pork with Oyster in Clay Pot - I only had the tofu in this dish, but it was tasty

Orange Sauce Pork Spareribs - we actually wanted orange chicken instead, but we were happy with this sweet mistake.

Overall, the service was fast and the food was very good. We will order from here again in the future.
author: Wesley S.

description: We just had our Chinese New Year dinner. It was alright. Peking duck was moist, skin was very dark and over cooked to the point that it was almost black. Lobster batter was soggy, hardly any meat. Veggies were crunchy.
author: Rickey Y.

description: They've been closed for a month.  HOPE THEY REOPENWe really enjoyed going there.  Certainly priced right.
author: DAVID W.

description: Not as good as I remembered but the food I had was pretty fresh. Has bathroom. accepts credit cards. Good service when fewer people. When it full, good luck. They have seafood here as well as most traditional Chinese food. Seating is good but a bit cramped in some places. They could clean their dishes and tables a bit better though. Owner is friendly and will assist you with your selection if you're not a decision maker. Price is good on the budget.
author: Alex C.

description:
If you're looking for quick and easy Chinese food, this is your go-to restaurant. This hole-in-the-wall restaurant is located on Taraval Street, very close to other Chinese bakeries and shops. Whenever we come here, we park across the street from the restaurant and walk over. Paying for parking is a hassle, but like with anywhere you visit in SF, there will always be parking meters. 

My family usually comes here for dinner after spending a day in San Francisco. We've been customers for many years now and like to order from their "set-list" menu, where the food is served banquet style. It's a pretty good way to order food and also get a variety of delicious flavors. You get soup to start with and dessert to finish! 

Environment:
Pretty small and enclosed space. Very loud whenever we go too. The noise level escalates very easily due to just how small the restaurant is. There aren't that many tables either, but we never have a problem getting seated right away. There are some round tables with the rest being regular rectangle ones. The kitchen is also located in the back, but noise from the cooking and preparation of the food travels all throughout the restaurant. 

Food:
I recommend their deep fried flounder fish with soy sauce! It's one of my favorites there! The fish is fried to the perfect level and the sauce that comes with it is amazing (not too salty). The Peking spare ribs, on the other hand, are mediocre. My sister thought that the sauce tasted very fake and artificial. They are also overly fried, which made the ribs very difficult to eat. I would also recommend the Mongolian beef and the chicken and salt fish fried rice! The Mongolian beef is very authentic and the chicken and the fried rice is just absolutely the most mouthwatering--love the seafood flavors that are packed in and you can really taste the heat from the wok in each bite! Lastly, you can't go wrong with any of their tofu dishes either! Love that food is all priced very inexpensively too! 

Service:
Eight Immortals does not focus on the presentation of the food. Like with most Chinese restaurants, you shouldn't expect to have the best experience when you dining here. The service is also on par with everything else here. Service is very prompt, but waitresses do not check up on you. If you need something, you really have to go out of your way to get their attention. The most they did was take our dishes away when the plates until we were finished. 

Last Thoughts:
I would say just let the food speak for itself!! Overall, my family still loves to come back and eat here every once in a while. Pretty great all around!
author: Rebecca C.

description:
The chickens wings are decently good, but the portions are definitely lacking... paid $91 for 3 items for catering, all the portions were tiny. About 3x less than what you would get from Chinese places around the area. 
Tldr; food is good, catering portions aren't worth it.
author: Ken H.

description: The tomato beef chow mein is excellent today.  Everything else was excellent today as well. The tea was very hot which we like.
author: Ed W.

description: Good service, clean Inside and restroom also clean , price not expensive and reasonable! The most important is the food is taste good , I think they don't put msg in the food not as other restaurants cuz after eat , u won't feel thirsty! Most Chinese restaurants they like put much msg in food but this restaurant they don't !
author: Bing L.

description: Horrible! Worst broccoli beef I've ever had! Ok so I'm working in he SF area with a crew, we all agreed on Chinese and this was the closest location. I looked online menu, I just wanted a side of broccoli beef it said it was only $4 so I figured it might be a small portion and got a appetizer pot stickers also $4 online. When we got there to pick up food she said it would be $17 something!???? I asked why she said "new prices" so I said I didn't want the pot stickers, she wouldn't let me take them off my order! So basically I had to pay for it all or not eat that night since we didn't have enough time to stop somewhere else. Finally got to sit down and eat and it was disgusting!!! The pot stickers were half burnt & half mushy, how does that even happen!?? The broccoli beef had a ton of ginger in it, after 2 bites I was sick. Horrible experience! I want a refund!
author: Cecilia A.

description: My family and I have been coming to 8 immortals for about a year now. We discovered them last Christmas when nothing else was open and have been in love ever since. They're (at least in part) a family run place, the woman in charge is no-nonsense and always available to make sure you have the best dining experience possible. They're authentic, efficient, and sometimes the language barrier makes for a slight mess up in the order but they're always quick to fix it. Plus, their shredded beef with pine nuts is absolutely to Die For!! We take all of our visiting family to try out 8 Immortals when they come to town and have yet to have anything but a great experience there. 10/10 recommend to any Asian food lover in the neighborhood
author: Hailee V.

description: Always great to come here for a take out when I am too busy to cook.  I usually cook veggies & rice at home and just buy the mains.  Today it's steam pork with salty egged and an order of salt & pepper pork ribs.  Sooo good and tender.  My local go to for take out Chinese food.  They have the $19.99 special ( till 5pm) which comes with rice & soup plus you choose 3 main dishes. Enough for 3 to 4 ppl.
author: Elaine Y.

description: Overcharged us on tax! Third time it's happened. They get upset whenever you try to have them correct the bill....something fishy's going on here.
author: Allan C.

description: Disgusting place. I have been exposed to this swill a few times as my father in law lives nearby and gets take out from there. The food is greasy and lacks flavor. Even just walking in and it smells gross.
author: Baba D.

description:
8 Immortals was everything I expected from the masses of cheap, dirty Chinese restaurants that plague this area.  Where one gets shut down another is teetering to keep its health score up.  The struggle is real here.  

The food is nothing short of your average drowned in a corn starchy sauce Chinese fare.  Fresh flavors are lacking here like cleanliness.  If it wasn't for family members, I would never have come here.  It was disheartening that I was unable to find a clean chair without some sort of wet substance or the idle attempts of wiping, only to leave visible smear marks  on the seat.  

I decided to order the shredded duck silver noodle soup with vegetables.  "Vegetables" was an overzealous listing as an ingredient with only sparse amounts of Chinese pickled greens.  In fact, the 5 or so "shreds" of duck and these bits of pickled greens, served as garnish to the heaping bowl of noodles sitting in a puddle of broth.  This bowl of soup noodles is the biggest joke of noodle soup I've seen in my entire life.  If I wanted a bowl of noodles, I would have just ordered that.  We ended up using all these noodles as rice with the main dishes.  The fried pork chops, fish with bok choy, beef & tofu and chicken and mushrooms can all be categorized the same way - average with mininal flavor, swimming in greasy sauce, and stingy with certain ingredients.

The service is on par with everything else here.  You won't get anything unless you make a serious effort to get someone's attention.  The heaps of empty plates and dirty dishes from our entire meal with all of us idling around the table waiting for the bill wasn't obvious enough to bring the bill. Boss lady got the sign finally when I stared at the kiosk long enough until she looked my way though.

I didn't find bugs in my food or see any cockroaches, but I wouldn't be surprised.  This restaurant's condition, food and service is sacrilegious to Chinese mythology's Eight Immortals.  Blasphemous!
author: Elizabeth S.

description: Don't go there.  Food is shitty .This place is a ripoff .  Went there for lunch. Order lunch special two dishes . She charge me for three dishes. Confront her . She told me I should have order three dishes instead.  Because I didn't order the third dish she is charging me for the rice. She told me It would be cheaper if I have order 3 dishes . What a scam,  no receipt either.  Can't wait til IRS audit
author: Joseph L.

description: This place served my co worker and I combination chow fun. The dish smelled like cat food and was the most disgusting Chinese food I've ever had in my life. The owners were watching tv in the dining area like it was there living room. It made it very awkward and uncomfortable. Don't waste your time here.
author: Lindsey W.

description: I am usually very doubtful about the quality of ANY Chinese restaurant in San Francisco because my family always takes us to restaurants where the atmosphere looks disgusting: floors aren't swept, tables are sticky, walls are dirty, restroom looks like they haven't been cleaned in months, and servers who always seem rush. But this place was surprisingly decent looking and the price was cheaper than what I would expect. All four of us each got one dish and the total turned out to be $40! Heads up they don't split checks to those who are paying with credit/debit cards so bring cash if you guys are planning on splitting the check. Our food was served within ten minutes after ordering. My boyfriend and I got the Mongolian beef on rice and it was delicious! The portion they serve you will definitely get you full when you walk in with an empty stomach. My little brother got the porridge which was on their "special menu" and he said it was flavorful but extremely hot. The portion of the porridge can definitely serve about two-three people as an "appetizer." They definitely do serve you fresh authentic Chinese food. Please don't expect amazing service and to be pampered like what you would receive from any other well trained restaurant. Service was good, but it's like your average family owned authentic Chinese restaurant where you have to flag them down for any request. Besides San Tung on Irving Street, Eight Immortal will definitely be one of my boyfriend's and my new go to places in the city when we're craving for Chinese food.
author: Jennifer L.

description: Came here for lunch and the food was salty and oily.  The portions are small and don't bother to try it.
author: David O.

description:
This place reminds me of the Chinese restaurants I grew up eating at when I lived in the Richmond District. It brought back a little nostalgia for me. 

I recently moved to the area and I can see this place being one of my new regular spots to grab a late night take out dinner. 

We ordered the beef with chinese broccoli (way better than regular beef with broccoli), chicken fried rice, and a won ton soup. YUM can't get any better than an OG chinese take out meal.
author: Dara S.

description:
3.5 stars seems just about right.
Trying to find those old time Cantonese style dishes is a difficult task when your parents are of that generation.  Not talking about HK nouvelle cuisine, but those classics like steamed salted egg or fish over pork, fried taro duck, and shrimp egg foo yung... wait a sec, what is that?!  
Back to my experience, I studied some Yelp photos from this sleepy Sunset mainstay, finding three attractive dishes for a recent dinner with my parents.  Here's what we ate:

1) Steamed razor clams (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=xud4P0ciA1UgVArGR1xO4w&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Presented in shell, medium slices topped a hefty bed of cellophane noodles.  As mentioned in some other reviews on other dishes, the flavor is on the bland side.  Not sure whether they forgot the soy green onion dipping sauce that usually accompanies this .

2) Taro duck (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=NUXlREghRzjiDhwqUZcKzQ&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - My memory of this is the fried taro puff dim sum sandwiching lean duck meat slices.  Their rendition is nicely fried (not too greasy), but the taro texture is on the dense side which lessened the crisp on this.

3) Steamed salted egg minced pork (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=lcLRWBMVlLa-FnGIdBiIXg&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Generous portion, the flavors were good though a tad on the dry side.  Perfect with a bowl of rice with a couple spoonfuls of the juice.

4). Foo Chow fried rice (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=LfiMjjwsVug0D4FXYuWYSw&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Again large portions, the flavors were nice as the chef has a light hand on salt and soy or oyster sauce.  Dominated by bay shrimp, there was a smattering of shiitake mushrooms, dried scallops, and sliced Chinese brocolli.

The food did not disappoint as the flavor profile fit our family's palate.  My father prefers heavier flavors which he satisfied by adding light soy sauce.  Just don't expect a HK gourmet meal at these prices here.  They also cooked and packed my order in about 20 minutes.  Parking here can be tough peak hours but, arriving at 5:45 pm on a Saturday, street parking was available.  May add this to the family dinner rotation.
author: Mike C.

description: We just had our Chinese New Year dinner. It was alright. Peking duck was moist, skin was very dark and over cooked to the point that it was almost black. Lobster batter was soggy, hardly any meat. Veggies were crunchy.
author: Wolfie M.

description: I was surprised they serve decent sweet and sour pork and pea sprouts. Will definitely come back!
author: Danae L.

description: Nice people, went in and enjoyed some delicious food with them right before they closed and they ate with us... We felt like part of the family :,)
author: Danny S.

description: I go primarily for the Wor Wonton soup. The Ginger Chicken with onion Clay Pot is good too.  the chow mein noodle dishes hit the spot. Seating is limited yet I've always have been seated and served in a timely manner. Very affordable. When I'm in the neighborhood it's near the top of my list.
author: Tyree J.

description: My party came in and sat at two circle tables with a total of 18 people and 10 of which are children. Clearly, we did not order separate bowls of rice for each of us children but only ordered a bin of rice which the children shared from. But the owner cheated us and charges each kid $1.50. They charged us that because they believed they gave all the children a bowl of rice. Clearly, that was wrong and we told them that we did not order and they insisted that we did order a bowl of rice for each of us. We were mad and paid for it anyway and have decided not to ever come back because of this rip-off. The restaurant had ripped chairs at the circle tables and not only that their dishes were messily served. For a vegetarian, there are very limited choices to make and eat. WE HIGHLY RECOMMEND AND WARN YOU NOT TO EAT HERE AND IF YOU STILL PLAN ON EATING HERE THEN CHECK YOUR BILL AND SEE IF THEY CHARGED YOU EXTRA FOR RICE. SMH ON THEM SMH. IF I COULD GIVE THEM A 0 I WOULD.
author: Emily N.

description:
Came here 2 weeks ago for an uncle's birthday party, and here's what we got: 

Sticky floors
Moldy chili sauce
Worms in the greens
Overcooked or yellowing vegetables
Old and mushy lobster
Empty stomachs

If this restaurant is still around anytime soon, it unfortunately is immortal.
author: Victoria M.

description:
Eight Immortals is THE restaurant my wife and I love to come to whenever we visit the city. The outside of the restaurant may not look like much... in fact... it is a very 'hole in the wall' type place, but the food is oh so tasty! And to top it off, it's reasonably priced too!

This year my family decided not to do the traditional huge Thanksgiving cook-off at home and came out to Eight Immortals for dinner. Like many Chinese restaurants, Eight Immortals IS open Thanksgiving day! The restaurant was abuzz with activity and people. I actually think the amount of people in the restaurant today was quite standard for a night here. This restaurant seems to be popular and frequented by people in the neighborhood.

Though there were many people we were still able to get a table pretty quickly. We were handed menus, but many of the best items can be ordered from the wall. Make sure you check the walls to see what special items they have!

Tonight was decided on some delicious chinese bean sprout leaves (these are AWESOME), half crispy chicken, fish, and two tofu dishes (one braised with vegetables and the other fried). I was a little hesitant to go for two tofu dishes... but I'm really glad we did because they were quite different from each other. The fried tofu squares were so good I think I could have eaten the whole thing by myself. I'd definitely recommend this dish if you come here. It comes out piping hot, and the tofu is perfectly crispy on the outside, melt in your mouth silky on the inside, and tastes amazing.

To finish the meal off, the server brought us red bean soup dessert - a wonderful ending to the meal.

Tonight our server talked to us a bit about his opinion about Black Friday. Though he was fluent in Cantonese, and spoke to us in Cantonese when we ordered... we actually carried on a conversation in perfect English too! I was a bit surprised... but I'm not sure why I should be!

Overall it was a great night out with delicious food and friendly service. I'm really looking forward to our next trip out to the city so we can come back here!
author: Luke C.

description:
We had there set price meal for $38 ($3 more for big fish) of minced beef w egg drop soup, deep fried flounder,  braised squab, mustard greens, and house dessert.  We added steamed rice, walnut prawn and tofu w 8 precious (combo meat & seafoods). It was great. 

The soup was hot and flavorfull. The braised squab was crispy not burnt. The sea salt portion was a little stingy but I love squab and this was a perfect appetizer. 

The deep fried flounder was larger than the large plate it came on. The sauce was under the fish rather than poured over the fish and really completes the fish. It was light crispy batter fried. Not greasy in the slightest,  nor did you get an oily after taste.

The walnut prawns were different than you usually get in the walnuts were roasted but not candied. Good, clean taste. The mustard greens were perfect not hard to chew or stringy. Even my F-I-L ate it up.
 
Last, but not the least, tofu w 8 precious clay pot was a feast... chicken, char siu, shrimp, baby octopus, squid and mushrooms all melded together in a tasty gravy. 

The house dessert was hot tapioca soup with an orange melon, pumpkin is my guess. I love tapioca. So I didn't need my son to tell me he didn't want his. I ate most of his too. I'm full and happy.
The whole meal was $68. No complaints.

My F-I-L was a pain about where we were going to sit but we still got service with a big smile. Great service, great food, we're going back next time we go out in SF.
author: Dave H.

description: My fav Chinese restaurant. Great fried rice, ma po tofu, and crispy salt and pepper treats (calamari, fish filet, etc.) Get there between 2pm and 5pm and you can get their Happy Hour menus. These are smaller portions, but great if you want to try something without getting a full-size order. Also good for quick small snacks in between meals. We particularly like getting a few Happy Hour items to snack on while we trek home with the rest of the take out meals. We usually over do it and over order and have leftovers for a couple extra days, which definitely satisfies us until the next time.
author: lucy l.

description:
This is our go-to Chinese takeout restaurant. We usually get a couple orders of the sticky rice and then switch up what meats/veggies we get (General Chicken is awesome). Service is always fast and friendly and the best part is the portion size. I'm a pretty big eater and we always have plenty of leftover food for a meal the next day; everyone knows the only thing better than Chinese takeout is leftover Chinese takeout. 

Also parking in the area is a little better than most places in SF so you won't be driving around 30 minutes looking for a spot.
author: Jonathan W.

description: Decent and still decent prices, but after eating here a couple of times recently, it isn't as good as it used to be. We don't really come here anymore. In a pinch, it'll do the job, but there are better Chinese places in the Sunset.
author: Dylan T.

description: Not the biggest fan of Chinese food, but I Love the general chicken and beef bean curds here! I will definitely be going back for more!
author: Michelle C.

description:
It's good cantonese food.  Smaller seating, but it's exactly what you order and expect.  

The food was fresh and hot! That's a first for me. How often do you get served hot chinese food from every dish? Not often.  So that means, they cooked it right then. No thoughts of, it's been sitting out waiting to be eaten.   Thats a star. 

Service, quick, cantonese/mandarin, and not pushy. Nice. Star.

Lots of variety to order from such a cheap menu. Not a limited menu either. Very eclectic. Star.

Apparently the bathrooms arent half-bad either. Star.

Why not 5 stars?  This is not some polite upscale restaraunt. This is comfort food we're talking about.
author: California K.

description:
Good simple food at a great price

This place has great promise to be our "go to" place when we're in the Sunset with our parents who prefer simple, well prepared Chinese with an eye for those on a limited budget. 

They have a 3 dishes for 19.99 offer that includes soup and rice.    We had a fried flounder, salt and pepper pork chops, and on choy, and ordered a forth dish of sautéed fish and veggies.  All dishes came out fast and steaming hot.   It was as if the cooks were listening to our order and started cooking immediately.  Either that or they have twenty guys back there doing the cooking.  Anyway it was fast.  

Food was fresh and tasty,   Especially the pork chops and fish.  

Service was very nice and friendly.  While we were there, at 3 pm, the place steadily filled with couples and families that were either having a very early meal or were having a very late lunch but everyone seemed to get the same prompt and friendly treatment.  

Would definitely come back and try their other dishes.
author: Bad News S.

description:
Sometimes you just need some quick and cheap Chinese take out.  In times like that, I think of 8 Immortals.  It's not too far from home and I know that I don't have to spend much and I'll get a lot of food.  It's pretty much the hole in the wall down the street that you can count on feeding a group of people and still having left overs.   

Over the weekend, friend called in an order for me to pick up for lunch.  We got 3 noodle dishes (beef chow fun, Singapore rice noodles, pork rice noodles), 2 house fried rice dishes (one with sauce and the other without) and 2 chicken/veggie stir-frys.  The potions are huge.  Of course, the quality isn't the best but it's alright.  You'll get some fatty meats mixed in there and maybe the veggies aren't the best, but everything is acceptable.  None of the dishes were too greasy or salty, like some other Chinese places nearby.  We fed 12 people for $39 and some change.  Can't really beat that when all are willing to carb it up.
author: Liv A.

description:
We came over to get food "to go".  Ordered about $60 worth of food.  The most expensive dish was the Walnut Prawns.  Then it's the chicken dish.  The container completely fell apart the to go bag.  Plastic in the food too!  Simply amazing.  It's as if the restaurant is buying lousy cheap containers to save money.   

The food is not that great.  But whatever.  But I will let my pictures tell the rest of the story.


I'm done with this place.
author: Miguel C.

description:
I used to go here with my family years ago. Back then there was a nice old man, the food was delicious, and the service was friendly. 

Now its surly service, luke warm food with small portions, and whack service. 

It's just all bad. We didn't eat much of our order and took it to go. The waiter managed to spill the food on the table. It's probably just gonna go in the trash. 

I really hate writing reviews like this, but it is what it is.
author: Theresa D.

description:
Cheap, fast Chinese food with okay service. 

Yeah it's one of those. Gets the job done, but really not worth going to again.
author: Alic H.

description: I came here lsat night after an appointment at UCSF & the food was just as much of a bargin & good as I remember it 10 years ago or maybe a bit less than that.  I love the casual atmosphere & friendly service.  The pot stickers are crispy golden with a wonderful ground pork, ginger, & cabbage mixture; perfect with the well balanced sweet & sour sauce.  Thje beef lo mein is okay; the beef could have3 more flavor, but everything else 0is wonderful including the wonderful egg thin noodles with a bit of wok char taste.  The sweet & sour spareribs are crispy with a lite badder & tangy Hong Kong style sweet & sour sauce; there is just enough to coat the ribs & no excess sauce.  The filet of rock dod with black bean sauce is flaky & tender with onions & green peppers in a flavorful black bean sauce.  Round it off with a Ching Dao or glass of wine & you will not be4 disappointed.  So, for some bargin Cantonese food in a friendly casual atmosphere, Eight Emortals cannot be beat.  Keep up the good work guys.
author: Brian S.

description: That short lady took my money! I gave her $5 and was expecting my change but she said i only gave $4. Its only a dollar but still, REALLY???? Learn to count lady
author: Ally G.

description: A warm sunny afternoon in San Francisco we were just coming from SFO and decided to drop in. To my surprise there was a parking spot on Taraval Street right in front. Free parking on Sundays that's great. We were a party of four and ordered our normal faire Peking Duck, Pork Fried Rice, Seasoned Greens with Garlic, Mongolian Beef, Deep Fried Flounder and Wonton Soup. Although the food was still good I took away 3 stars because number one our waiter seemed to intentionally place his thumb in all four of our soup bowls! Lucky thing they gave us all a glass of water I hope he didn't place his fingers inside each cup?  I then used the water  to wipe the bowls out. About fifteen minutes into our meal I saw the waiter off to the side playing with his cell phone? People please leave your phones alone while you are on duty. Is it too much for you to wait until your break? I have never seen him before so maybe he is new. The wait staff that the previous owners employed were much more professional. One more thing since we did request soft drinks and on warm days like today maybe next time you could give us some glasses with some ice cubes in them? It's not the same place anymore.
author: John W.

description: Prices are reasonable but that's the only good thing....  Food is substandard (Panda Express is even better).  Also the cashier needs to learn the concept of customer appreciation
author: G. R.

description: My family and I attended a two-table banquet on the 2nd floor. The ceiling fans apparently were not cleaned because when they were turned on, there was dust and black particles blowing out from the fans and landing on the food! My cousin's girlfriend's glass of water had particles of gray and black dust floating on the surface of the water. There was dust also landing on our white plates! Some of the food ordered was cold and the clams and steamed fish were not fresh. We will not be going back to this place. I think this restaurant should be called, "8 Mortals" because 8 of us may all get sick or die of pathogenic complications. Where are the health inspectors when you need them?!
author: Andrew P.

description: Don't ever ever go to this shitty restaurant. First of all the service here are terrible. Second they have this rude ass Chinese lady in the cash register. And third everything is dirty and a mess. Fourth I found a bug in my food and they did not give me a refund or anything. It's so fucking rude that they will not get my refund while there's a dead bug on it and especially how the lady in the cash register wearing all black was ignoring me and being rude. This place is disgusting and needs to be shit down or make everything better. Especially there employees. So guys I do not recommend going here. It's a fucking nightmare dump.
author: Mark Crisher U.

description: We've been coming here for years. The food is great, the service is fast and it's very inexpensive, especially for the amount of food you get. We have hosted two dinner parties here and both times the service was great and our friends liked the food. If you're in the area, check it out!
author: wendy w.

description:
76 out of 100 for a health score scares me. And, that reminds me, I still have to get my flu shot for this year.

I've tried two things at this restaurant. Their sweet and sour sizzling steak, and their fried squab.

The sweet and sour steak was pretty good, but man were the portions big. I'm not asking for a Hungry Man sized portion, but a few strips of beef and 3 scoops of rice really? I'm not a big fan of cheating people with the rice. I mean, save the rice for someone who orders fried rice.

The fried squab was overly fried. It was definitely dead. And chewy. And burned.
author: Jack R.

description: Just had dinner there with a group of friends after a day at the museum.  I've never been there before but was attracted to the establishment as it looks like its been there forever.  Long story short, the food was good and the prices were cheap.  This business survived and made it through so many years...yelp shouldn't have any affect on how this business does except bring in new customers.
author: Samuel K.

description: We are here for my aunts birthday. The food was good. We had a variety of things. The food came out fresh and fast which is always a plus. AND then .....it happened! There was a pincher bug in our fried rice and several of nats on our honey walnut prawns. After showing the waiter he rushed back to the kitchen and made another rice and apologized. With the prawns they took them tp the back, never offered us another one and we didn't hear anything else about it. After the second batch we found another odd specimen. I'm totally disgusted and won't be returning here ever! !!!
author: Schanta L.

description: This place was pretty awesome! My boyfriend and I came to this place randomly, we didn't have to yelp it or anything. We ordered Mongolian Beef, Beef Chow Mein and Salt& pepper pork chops AMAZING! And if other people are coming in here and the owner is calling you by your first name, you know it's that good!
author: Catherine B.

description:
Not a bad place at all,  came here a few times for dinner and lunch before. 

My favorite for dinner is the seafood set menu. It literally has everything you can think of - jellyfish, lobster, crab, clams, and more. And the price wasn't bad at all since it fed 6 people with tons of extra to take back home. 
The highlight of this set would be the jellyfish for me. 

Other food: 
Minced beef with raw egg over rice - Pretty damn good and cheap. Only best while its hot and fresh. The quality seems to decrease significantly if you ordered take out. 

Beef lo mein- Wasn't impressed with this, I felt like it lacked flavor

crispy taro duck - I actually liked this one a lot too, a great to snack when you're at home.

The thing I'm looking forward to the most would be that seafood dinner set. Let's hope my boyfriend's want to go there again some time soon ;9
author: Harriet W.

description:
Although this place is small, the food is excellent.  Not too oily and quite tasty.  And usually not much wait.  We live not too far away, and once we discovered this place, we have been coming by often.

Def. a place to try if you are nearby.. very reasonable price, too!
author: Kathy C.

description:
I love this place, all the everybody has a great sense of humor and the food is delicious!

I came here a bit skeptical since the prices were so low I didn't expect much, but I was surprised to find it was some of the best fried rice I ever tasted/

Edit: I made my original review in high school coming back the quality of the food has definitely declined.
author: John V.

description:
Haven't been to 8 Immortals since high school. My family and I came here for lunch today and I can easily say this is our new Sunday lunch choice! Not only are the dishes reasonably priced, the food isn't too bad!

I loved all the dishes that we ordered today, except maybe one or two because they were kind of salty, but still delicious. We ordered some dishes from the specials menu and the rest from their 3 for $19.99 menu which included the house soup and rice! Our dishes were;
1. Spinch with beef - tasteless but good
2. Mongolian beef - a favorite, though spicy at all
3. Scrambled egg with shrimp - so good, and lots of shrimp!
4. Tripe - tasteless but still good
5. Pig stomach - pretty good! (tasted like seaweed salad)
6. Pork spareribs - delicious but probably the highest in sodium
7. Salty tofu cubes - just fried tofu with salt, still good
8. Pork with string beans - salty but very good

They have happy hour from 2 p.m. - 5 p.m. and that means $1 drinks! The milk tea cup was gigantic! Definitely a good deal to come during happy hour. 

The staff is very friendly and they seem to be proficient enough in English for us non-Cantonese speakers. 

I give this place an A
author: Alex T.

description:
Just came here this past weekend during my little weekend get away in SF and I was very happy with this restaurant. 

Service was great although they kept pushing us to get the preset family deals, we chose to get individual plates and share them family style.  We ad the deep fried flounder, salt and pepper calamari, seafood fried rice, and peking spare ribs. All of the food was delicious and portions were average but for an overall price of $32 dollars, it beats out a lot of places in my book. 

Service was friendly and the food didn't take too long to come out. 

My friend also told me about this 3 entree's for $20 deal but its only offered before 4pm or something like that. Overall, definitely a place to eat if you and your friends are on a budget.
author: Alvin L.

description:
One of best wor wonton soups I've ever had had....yums!!!!  .....service not so great but the food is tasty! Most of the other dishes are as good any other good Chinese cuisine you'd probably find in the city..... Really decent pricing!!!
Service ok....it seems like they don't like black people .....that's why they didn't get 5 stars in my book
author: Idi W.

description: Nice Chinese Cuisine at Affordable Prices. I love the Buddhist Delight with Bean curd, Honey Walnut Prawn, Singapore Rice Chow Fun, Fried Flounder / Sole Fish, Potsticker
author: Chanh N.

description:
Eight Immortals is quite the hidden gem in the Parkside district and I definitely recommend it! 

This place is perfect for take out and I really wish they had delivery! However, every time I have ever dined in or ordered take out, it is ALWAYS packed (and there's obviously a reason for that)!

Please note - this place isn't fancy at all. I usually come here in sweats, with my hair up and glasses. However, this place is absolutely delicious and very well priced. Plus, the service is great - they speak English (yup, that's a rare thing at many Chinese restaurants in the city). I believe this place is family owned because for years, I have seen the same sweet lady at the front desk, her husband (I think) who deals with counting the cash and her son who runs around waiting on everyone. I'm a fan of family run businesses, so if this is the case, props to these people!

The food is really yummy here! I HIGHLY recommend getting their noodles, hong kong style. The egg noodles come crispy with a yummy gravy sauce on top of them. I literally crave these noodles on the daily (oink, oink). Also, their salt & pepper shrimp are great and so are their honey walnut prawns. My mom loves their whole steamed fish (although she secretly loves their deep fried whole fish) and my dad loves their beef & broccoli. 

Parking is easy! Fellow yelpers, when you're feeling lazy and in the mood for some yummy take out, come here!
author: Anastasia N.

description:
8 immoral things in the restaurant.

1. 63 out of 100?!! OMFG! ( now, it's 72, so what?)

2. Minced Beef with Raw Egg Over Rice in a restaurant that health cord is 63?

3. Hot and sour soup was bland and smelled like pinesol mop water.

4. Mongolian beef was slimy and rubbery.

5. Took one bite of the prawns with lobster sauce and was ready to run for my life.

6. Fried rice had to have been days old.

7. Dirty, disgusting, you will crossing fingers that wishing not to get poisoned.

8. Wanted to ask for my fucking money back.

The 8 is enough.

That's immoral right there. Failing to adhere to moral standards. 
Not conforming to accepted standards of morality.
An immoral person commits acts that violate society's moral norms. 
An amoral person has no understanding of these norms, or no sense of right and wrong.

Any restaurants should not be 63.

Well, 72 now.

8 Immoral things in the restaurant.

Oh Hell.
author: Nobu K.

description:
It was that time of year again, but this time, the year of the snake.  Chinese New Year is not Chinese New Year without a big ass feast (dominated by seafood) to mark the occasion so I joined my family for some of annual grubbing.  It's quite possibly the most delicious time of the year.

The meal started with some tofu soup which was hot and warmed the soul as it went down.  With that came the jelly fish course which was briny and crunchy, and tasted of the sea.  The main courses came out about this time and was made up of a stir-fried lobster with garlic sauce, stir-fried crab in ginger sauce, salt and pepper pork chops, steamed shrimp, scallops with squid and vegetables, fried sand dab, stir-fried clams in black bean sauce, fried calamari, and of course steamed rice.  My favorites were the pork chops and lobster, those the shell fish is always a little bit of a pain to eat.  It was all pretty good but I will say it wasn't the best Chinese food I've ever eaten.  The fish was WAY overcooked and might have been old to boot.  The fried calamari was also overdone.  Despite that, I'll never turn down a Chinese feast and I'm always up for cleaning my plate when there's food around.

Service was pretty dismal all night and they were totally slammed.  In fact, we didn't even get out dessert soup as we were practically forced out the door to make room for another party.  This was pretty rude but the staff really didn't give a damn what we thought.  I'm never a fan of that attitude when it comes to providing a good dining experience and would seriously consider other places to eat before returning here.

Food: 7/10

Service: 2/10

Price: $$

Atmosphere: 5/10
author: Joe M.

description:
Ehhh.. Don't know what all the hype is about.  This restaurant lacks anything that makes it stand out.  It is over-crowded and the customer service is horrible.  My family made "reservations" to come eat at 7:30pm. on a Saturday night.  When we came at 7:15 pm., they said it would take us 15 minutes to be seated.  After waiting 45 minutes, we were finally seated.  We were told we would get a table in the back because it was bigger, but we were lied to, and seated in the main eating area.  There were 13 of us and it was crowded.  We were sitting so close to each other it was uncomfortable.  

The fish tank had but 1 fish, looking like it was ready to die from the murky water.  

Service was horrible.  We asked to get another chair because there were only 12, and they seemed to forget 3 seconds later after we asked.  It appears they can't count either because they only gave us 12 plates.  

We ordered the $220 set meal.  It was okay... Nothing special.  

This place just seems like your typical Chinese restaurant.  Yet, there are so many better places that do not require a long wait.  

Despite my review, this place will still continue to get lots of business with people waiting outside the door.  Sigh.
author: Victor L.

description: In case you haven't noticed, the high rent has driven the majority of the really good Chinese restaurants out of the city. When they try to raise prices, consumers turn up their noses because how dare they charge you an extra dollar or two for chow fun or sweet and sour chicken!? I don't know how Eight Immortals do it, but portions are huge, quality of seafood has always been fresh, and prices are reasonable. Not the best, but it's kept me coming here for over a decade now.
author: Soo L.

description:
The BF wanted to give this 4, but I decided on 3.  I enjoyed the beginning free soup quite a lot actually.  It had a strong star of anise flavor in it that reminded me of home soups.  It did, however, have a interesting brown murky color that was a little offputting before I tried it.

I came here with 5 people, so we ordered 6 dishes and ALMOST almost finished it all.  We got 2 different types of spareribs, a chinese spinach/vegetable dish, a fish, tofu, and pork hot pot, a dried scallop and tofu dish, and a mongolian beef dish.

So here goes.  The fish, tofu, and pork hot pot was pretty good.  Granted, there as more tofu than anything, and there really wasn't any pork--just bits of like fat for flavor.  It also had those fat black chinese mushrooms that I love.  The fish was good.  

The dried scallop and tofu dish was alright.  It was probably my fault for ordering it because I wasn't quite sure what dried scallops are.  Now i know.  And I know it's alright.  Also, i'm 96% sure that the menu fish said FRIED tofu, and it was not fried.  I guess it made it more healthy.  It kind of tasted like cuttlefish to me.  

The chinese spinach was good.  period.

The 2 spareribs dishes were good, but overall not outstanding,

The mongolian beef had little beef, and just didn't taste like mongolian beef.  It had a lot of onions, which I actually like.  So no issue with the dish, except it was not what I was expecting.

Parking was easy.  I would come back.  Probably.  Maybe.
author: Aly A.

description: I came here for a fam dinner of 10 last night, knowing they have been declining in terms of quality. Sadly I will likely not be coming back anymore. I figured the food quality was not up to par since the restaurant is usually fairly empty, meaning the freshness of food goes bad waiting to be cooked. Portions aren't like they used to be as well. Good bye 8 immortals, it's been fun while it lasted all these years..
author: elaine w.

description: I know you're not expected to get stellar service at authentic chinese restaurants, but this place was pretty rude.  We arrived about 12 minutes to 5pm on a Saturday,  but the company I was with was hampered by a disability and was also not accustomed to ordering Chinese cuisine so as a result, a family that arrived after us was waited on before us.   We had to flag down the waiter even though the restaurant was empty aside from us and the other family.  I wanted to order from the special pink menu that is written in Chinese and has many inexpensive items.  We weren't given one of these menus' probably because we weren't all Chinese.  I asked if I could order from the special menu but they said that it ended at 5 O'clock and it was now a few minutes past that time.  The family that came in after us ordered from this menu just a minute before!  As a result many of the dishes, like Chinese broccoli, we're more than twice the cost.  The lady who took our order was quite rude and seemed very impatient with us.   The food was fine but nothing distinctive.   We had sweet and sour pork, Chinese broccoli, cashew chicken and a Buddhist delight.
author: P. O.

description:
Their service sucks donkey balls. The food is ALMOST mediocre at best, but most dishes can be too salty.
This place has definitely gone downhill over the years. 
The last time I went (a couple of weeks ago) I had the saltiest freaking fish of my life. I was chugging water and shoveling rice down my throat to try to wash down the sodium + msg.

Portions vary depending on which cook makes your food too.
author: Susy C.

description:
Truly a Seafood Lover's delight; however, it is equally great for meat-eaters as well!  So many delicious items on the menu, I can honestly say that everything I've ordered on their menu,  just tastes soooo good!!!!

Here are my favorites:  
-Salt & Pepper Squid
-Deep Fried Bean Curd
-Dry Scallops & Egg White Fried Rice
-Scallops & Shrimp w/ Greens
-Honey Walnut Shrimp
-Squid with Tender Greens
author: Ann E.

description: If you want good and cheap Chinese food come here.  I get the standard fare.  Mongolian beef, salt and pepper squid, sweet & sour pork, garlic scallops and of course yang chow fried rice.  It's a bit on the outskirts of San Francisco but I always enjoy my meal at 8 Immortals!
author: Maria M.

description: I would have given this place a 3 or 4 until the bill was due.  After the owner/manager found out who paid it, he made a point of shaming my party until he got a better tip! He went on and on about whether he attended to us and brought us water.  Funny thing was, he didn't bring us the water, another staff member did.  He even pointed out the desired tip amount.  He also mentioned that at that restaurant the tip was not reflected in the bill.  My tip would have been don't be an asshole to your customers.  Never eating here again, and will pass the word to family members, acquaintances and fellow Yelpers.
author: Filomeno Lex N.

description:
If you love laser eyes from management, then you'll love this place. 

They watch over you like a hawk as if you are going to steal something, and they are kind of rude. As soon as you sit down, their duties are to get your food, refreshments, and refills, anything after that, nope. we ordered the 50 dollar platter and we wanted to replace an item that we did not like. But getting to replace the item was like pulling teeth. 

The food was ok, and the service was terrible. 8 immortals, more like 5 managers asking you to leave with their deathly stares.
author: Richard A.

description:
Eight Immortals is the perfect San Francisco family restaurant. 

It's raining in December when my family unloads two cars of people into Eight Immortal's cramped waiting area. Thirteen families averaging eight people per table, share large passed plates of glossy, good-looking stuff. Is it rude to point and say "I want what they are having?" 

A compliment to the chef, my family is the only one of European ancestry. The wait is short. One thing to note. There are no parties of one or two here. 

This place was made for families. The largest tables don lazy Susans. ( a device which acts as a rotating platter on the table) It is the perfect way to share platters of food. 

We read the specials that were in English on the wall, which listed the more rare seasonal dishes. There were some neat ones! Whole crab, whole steamed bass and interesting animals and organ parts like frogs and faces etc. I am almost kidding about the face part. Were my skittish family not with me, I would have gone for an exotic item to have tried it for the first time. Like Anthony Bourdain! 

After making my food allergies very clear to our server, we ordered the whole steamed bass. One and a half pounds at $12.99 per pound, mixed vegetables with mushrooms in clear garlic sauce, combination seafood flat rice noodles, (no gravy) chicken curry, rice and tea for the table. 

Gluten free friends, Chinese food is very hard to eat for us. We can not eat soy sauce, black bean sauce, barbecued meats, marinated meats, oyster sauce, Hoisin sauce, dumplings or hot and sour soup. What is left? Clear sauce, egg drop soup (no egg noodles) and curry. Be very clear about the "clear" part. If your food has any tint of brown color anywhere, chances are that you are allergic to it. 

The good news is that you can have rice and rice pastas etc. This restaurant is a wonderful treat for my gluten free friends who take the time to be clear about their allergies. Only clear sauce! No gravy! 

The whole steamed bass was covered in shredded Chinese leeks.(four stars) My sister said: "It's looking at me!" Ha ha! It was accompanied by a very good sauce of yellow broth and crunchy garlic for me and traditional brown sauce as well for the family. I was confident that my sauce was superior and confirmed it when my family preferred my sauce to theirs when seasoning the bass. (five stars) 

The vegetables were good, not great, (3.5 stars) the curry chicken was very mild with large chunks of potato, the sauce was a little thin for my taste (3.5 stars) 

Our favorite dish was the rice pasta with combination seafood. (five stars) We ordered more, we liked it so much. Gluten free friends, rice pasta, made fresh, is even better than the egg noodles off limits to you! Large flat rice noodles with fresh bok choy, shrimp and squid. This dish is traditionally made with soy sauce but can be made with nothing but salt on request. It is light, delicate and de-freaking-licious. They don't punk out on he seafood here friends. The large portion of shellfish makes this dish an outstanding value at only $6. 

The menu is huge, the service is good, the prices are obscenely affordable, the food is great. Especially for my wheat allergies. The emphasis here is on family food. Well done Eight Immortals. 

Viva familia:-)
author: Mary B.

description:
Good food and good portions for a cheap price. Happy hour from 3-5pm where special menu items are only $2. 

The only problem I have with this place is, nobody here seems to speak English. I know it is a Chinese restaurant but everyone that works here seems to not understand a lick of it. I ordered salt and pepper fish filet TWICE here, I pointed to it on the menu and the waiter repeated back my order "filet" and confusingly nodded his head. I did not get my order, I got a different filet order on two different occasion after saying I wanted salt and pepper fish filet. It was very unfortunate because the salt and pepper fish filet is the only reason I really come here. I came here 3 times to get it, and they confused it twice due to a language barrier.
author: Wells Y.

description:
My brother discovered this place when he was in HS. He took our family here once time and since then I love the wonton "E Fu" soup. I never had it anywhere else so this is the place I go when I crave it! It is made of fried wontons boils in egg broth. I like how its not to salty and has the right amount of taste. 

This place is inexpensive and have lots of seating. From my memory, I never had to wait to get a table. This is not a fancy restaurant but the food here are good and people here are nice.
author: Tiffany C.

description: Everything on the menu is very reasonably priced, and the people who own the place are friendly! It's a pretty stereotypical Chinese restaurant but there's absolutely nothing wrong with that. I always order a big bowl of wonton soup all for myself, however, I've had several other items on the menu as well and I enjoyed them!
author: Catherine L.

description:
Got to-go with the boyfriend and his cousins. So this means we had like 8 orders. The service was quick, friendly, and super helpful, but the food did take a while to come out. I'll give them a pass though since it was a good number of orders (but it really could have been faster). 

The waitress that brought out our food took the extra time to ask us which orders belonged to who so she could bag them together for us. I thought that was really nice :) 

They have $1 milk tea and INCA COLA. Both are delicious and highly recommended. 

The food: the portions were average but good. Everyone was pretty happy with theirs as far as taste, but we have quite a few growing boys so they demolished their portions. What I got was that the noodle/chow fun dishes are tastier than the rice dishes.
author: Chloe T.

description:
The selfish me says not to even rate this place because it is small and the dishes are inexpensive and the food is incredible, and if word gets out then there will be a long wait and the prices will sky rocket. Then again all of you trendy hipsters and foodies who can't see beyond the corporacracy restaurateurs as seen on The Food Network "in scene" probably would never venture out to sleepy 25th and Taraval anyway.

If however you are interested in authentic Chinese cuisine at it's best then 8 Immortals will not disappoint you. The staff is friendly, helpful in assisting with picking dishes and the prices are downright cheap.

Sizzling Rice Soup looked rather odd and lacking in content except for sizable pieces of tomato however had a lovely flavor with just the perfect amount of pepper

For those of you out there that are still hell bent on eating every Chilean Sea Bass out of the sea, I think you might find a new love if you dared to try the hideously ugly and quite plentiful local Rock Cod in tender greens. Succulent, moist, plump, ivory white morsels of incredibly fresh fish in a light garlic sauce on a bed of baby bok choy. Simple yet unbelievably incredible seafood dish.

Clay Pot with Chicken, Ginger and Scallions. Sounds simple and boring huh? Well think again. The dish arrived  bubbling hot and loaded with huge chunks of fresh ginger and I do mean huge. Of course you don't eat the ginger but the savory brown sauce and the chicken infused with the spicy ginger along with the scallions was this side of Heaven.

Hong Kong style noodles with sliced beef was perfectly executed and delicious.

Sauteed A-Choy (That's a green vegetable native of south Taiwan) tender, flavorful and so fresh tasting you'd swear it was picked from a garden moments before. Yummy!
author: Steven B.

description: We keep coming back for their scallop fried rice, beef chow Mein and their deep fried tofu with shrimp on top. The owner/manager has great memory that's why my family and I feel at home whenever we visit and dine here.
author: Leslie S.

description: Definitely oily chinese food. Extra star because they have good cheap prices during their happy hour and drinks are only  $1-$2. Typical oily chinese food with decent service. Their service is definitely better for frequent customers rather than new comers.
author: Jessica W.

description:
UPDATE:  I thought I'd try this place again and there are new owners.  I ordered take out since we were in a bit of a rush.  Ordered the standard chow-fun and chow-mean dishes.  This time the food was WAY greasy and not sure what happened.  But I'm keeping it at three stars since I do want these folks to do well and have employment for those working there.  

Found out that the old owners took their chef and went to the restaurant on 22nd & Vicente.  Need to check that out too!
author: Stefan L.

description:
No frills lunch spot for rice plates and noodles.

8 Immortals is my go-to spot for a cheap meal when craving simple Chinese comfort foods.  I regular this spot for lunch for their amazingly cheap lunch prices.  Rice plates range from $4.75-$6.00.  Can't beat it! 

Aside from being extremely reasonably priced,  I really enjoy the food here too.  Cheap and good is a rare combo these days.   

For the portion size, they could easily be charging a bit more, but they don't. No complaints here.  What I come for are simple dishes that satisfy those cravings. 

My favorite comfort dish is Minced Beef with Raw Egg Over Rice.  What I love about this dish in comparison to other restaurants that also serve it, is that they included peas, carrots and chopped onions to add that extra flavor. I've had this dish at plenty of places before that most spots only give you peas for texture. Saucy and flavor, and just the way I like it. If this doesn't scream simple and comforting Chinese food, then I don't know what else does.
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/R7QrC8pX9luLd5cx3Fzl3A?select=zLb5aTwZkdrrhGjQAqOFZA

I also like to order their noodle dishes for lunch as well.  Other favorites are the Hong Kong Style Combination Noodles and the Tomato Beef Chow Mein.

What's nice about the Combination Noodles is that there's plenty of variety.  Good options for seafood, and for meat in one dish.  Included are BBQ Pork (Cha Siew), Chicken, and pieces of Beef.  There's also Prawns, Scallops and Calamari, and of course your much needed Bok Choy.
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/R7QrC8pX9luLd5cx3Fzl3A?select=rUjZjgAS6nlQpMEu2aWByg

Tomato Beef is also quite flavorful and included good pieces of beef.  They definitely don't skimp on pieces and cut them into little tender slices. 
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/R7QrC8pX9luLd5cx3Fzl3A?select=HRcuE834sVOAQaXS4tmEaA

Overall, simple lunch for simple cravings.  Price and portion size can't be better.  I don't remember the last time I've seen a lunch plate priced at 4 bucks in a long time! 

Until next time...
author: Cass J.

description:
Used to come here ALL DEEE TIMEEE with family from when I was a young baby to teenage and young adult years. Haven't been here lately because prices rose a lot from back then, but nevertheless they still serve really great food.

Although the place is not the cleanest or nicest restaurant there is, the quality of the food is not diminished. They have really good fish, such as deep fried flounder. Their orange chicken is BOMB and would always be requested by the younger kids. They have pretty good fried rice and all their seafood is really good.

They have a 'party' room upstairs, well not really a party, but the room where you would have huge family events. With kids running around and adults having a great time as well, WITH great food also, what more can you ask for??

They also give out dessert after the meals that aren't just some shabby little gift to give away. Their desserts, whether it be red bean soup thing with little white tapioca, or their cold fruit cocktails, it would always be top notch dessert to follow up the top notch meal.

I've never left there unsatisfied.
author: Benjamin W.

description:
This is legit Chinese food!! Mediocre to crappy service, amazing food, cheap prices, that's what it's all about!! Haha. 

Come here early, like 6-6.30pm. Anytime after that, you'll be waiting for a while! I think it's related to good luck or something, but some Chinese people thinks that if you change something that's going well, you'll ruin it. That's why I know the owner of this place can easily move this restaurant and find a bigger space. But I bet he thinks it's bad luck. With the way business is going in this place, owner must be well cushioned for retirement. I love his hard working attitude though. He is always here, almost every single day, along with his wife. They make sure things run smoothly and employee acts accordingly. That is the sign of a very excellent owner!

Anyway, entrees are pretty cheap here, considering this is SF and everything is overpriced. They have a great selection of food, and if you speak Chinese, you can pretty much ask for anything and they'll make it for you. The quality of food is 100% consistently really good, always!! It's not too greasy, the portions are sufficiently generous, and they do not hold anything back for the sake of money in order for customers to be happy with the food. You can order pretty much anything and you'll be happy here! Although I like it when they have specials on crabs and lobsters, good price, large portion, very satisfied!!

Downside is the small bathroom, mediocre service, small room in general, long wait times if you come during the dinner rush hour. Place is not updated decor-wise, but it's not unclean. 

Verdict: This place is awesome!!!
author: Andrew I.

description: Steamed fish dishes are the best in the SF Bay Area. Seating is too tight, dishes start to get saltier and saltier. Sorry, being healthy is becoming more and more focus of concern.
author: Larry L.

description:
Parking was very easy.  We parked only half a block away.  We were seated right away without waiting.  

Within 10 minutes after our order, we were served with Westlake Beef soup, Beef Steak Cube with Chinese Broccoli, Oyster, Pork and Tofu Clay Pot and Shredded Pork Chow Mein.  They were all delicious and with very generous portion.  

The service was attentive and timely.  I dropped my chopsticks by accident and were promptly replaced with a fresh pair without asking.  We also had our ice water filled a few times (without asking) which was quite unusual.  It must be a slow night for them.

For service, it is definitively a 5-star.  For food tastiness, it is 5-star.  For ambiance, it is a hole in the wall, neighborhood kind of  place, it is a 2-star.  Mathematically, if they are all equally weighted, it will be a 4-star but the definition of a 4-star is for a fan whom I can't say that I am so I rated it a 3-star overall.  It is definitely a OK place to go for a quick-bite for sure.
author: Thomas L.

description: Great for take out! Very reasonable and the food is yummy. I like the combination chow mein in particular.
author: Nancy G.

description: I love this place. great service, small local restaurant and the food is priced well and taste great! they even have a happy hour menu offered mid day.
author: Serena L.

description:
This place used to be good, not great, but now that they've switched owners, it's awful.

Back in the day my family would always come to this restaurant, and it was decent Hong Kong family food. As a child, I wasn't so picky. As long as I got an Inca Cola, I would eat whatever supposedly good-for-me seafood they would shove my way. Looking back though, I wouldn't  eat there now. The food is quite heavy, and filled with msg. Every dish save the white rice seems to be sprayed with oil. It's as though they use oil instead of another seasoning to dress the food before it can go out. 

Recently, I guess my family felt pangs of nostalgia, we decided to eat there again. We knew that the previous owners had retired, but we wanted to see that one kind faced and dimpled smiling waitress who had watched me grow up. We wanted her to take our order as she'd done so many times in the past. As though it were justification for our being there, an acknowledgement that though the passage of time can bring sudden change, pleasant reminders of the past are still around if you look closely enough.

But the food was sh*t. Everything tasted like it came out from cans of Chef Boyarechi. Eugh, never going there again.

Star for that waitress, another star for nostalgia, one more star for Inca Colas, and finally, a negative star for horrible food.
author: Alan H.

description:
This use to be one of our favorite "hole-in-the-wall".  Good and reasonable price food.  Its a small restaurant with a capacity of about 50.  Since the change in ownership, the service level has declined to #&&*/&&.  

Despite the lack of service, it was entertaining to see the service staff running around chanting "boss lady".  That was their polite way of addressing her.  It was like watching a old Chinsee kung fu movie with the boss lady sitting in the store front collecting money.

We were seated at this weird table that were two "four tops" put together.  I guess the purpose was to seat 6 but is was jammed in between two tablest so you really couldn't sit two people at the end.  We didn't like the configuration so we asked to change tables.  The people at the end could not reach the food at the other end because of the length of the table.  So instead of just moving it to the new table, the waiter cleared the new table and literally moved everything from the old table...placements etal.  Tacky...really tacky or pure inexperience.

Our meal for the evening consisted of deep fried flounder, crispy chicken, salt and pepper ribs, walnut shrimp, mustard greens and steamed eggs with clams.

The deep fried flounder was cooked to the right temperature.  The mustard greens was slightly oily.  The chips on the crispy chicken was soggy and stale...ca't anyone fry it correctly.  The salt and pepper was more salt than pepper.  The walnut shrimp was soggy and the walnut were stale.  The steamed eggs was cooked nice...good favor.

Despite the food's short fall, it was still an ok meal.  Their downfall was service and its apparent because the senior waiter was constantly teaching the others...it was like this the last time we were there.  

The million dollar question...will I go back.  MAYBE?
author: MickYee M.

description: Not bad. Good family restaurant. Will mos def come back. Prices are reasonable! Food is great. Everything is good...
author: Stephen H.

description: The BBQ fried rice, was neither fried and all rice. The egg flour soup, was disgusting. There are so many better options within walking distance of this place, I won't bother returning.
author: Anthony M.

description:
Went to lunch with 5 Chinese friends who know their food.  We had pre-ordered one of the wo choy menus plus an additional dish.  We got there at 11:00 am to avoid the lunch rush.  Soup was ok but very, very bland.  Dishes started coming out pretty quickly and universally I can say that every dish was almost totally without flavor.  I know that Cantonese food is mild, but it should have some flavor!  Then after 4-5 dishes had been served we get the news that the extra dish we wanted was not available - even though we had ordered it 5 days ahead of time!  So we ordered another dish.  Then the extra dish that we originally wanted that wasn't available suddenly makes an appearance.  This did not sit well with my Chinese friends - they felt that we had just been nudged into ordering more food than we really wanted...

Then about 3 dozen Lincoln High School kids trooped in to order their fried rice - the noise level went up so high that we could no longer converse among ourselves.  

So, after you read this, you still want to eat pretty flavorless, not very well prepared food in somewhat mingy portions, don't go at lunch time on a weekday - unless you like lots of loud teenagers.

Better yet, go down the street and go to Ming's Diner - much better food!
author: Karen M.

description: Had the special for 2 dinner, Cantonese!  Dumpling soup was good a little too salty but good!  Pork fried rice was good!  The sweet and sour pork had a good flavor!  The beef with vegetables was horrible, no flavor, beef not properly cooked and we didn't eat it!  We also shared the salt & pepper calamari because I read on a review it was amazing, it was ok, fried with no flavor!  Had a Coke and a glass of water and the lady at the register put her fingers in the water pitcher and she was handling money at the register!  Overall not a place I will come back to!
author: Hugo C.

description:
Haven't been back in years since an incident that happened.  Was just finishing dinner there and saw these two rather large cockroach scurrying up the wall.  They were good size cockroach similar to the ones you see in tropical climates.  Just a bit unappetizing for me. Im sure that all restaurants have some sort of infestation problem but prefer not to see while im in the establishment. 

I was just looking at the reviews for Lychee restaurant on Irving and saw a review that mentioned the eight immortals so decided to see if they are still around.
author: brian l.

description:
They are located further out on Taraval at around 24th Ave, so you might have some good luck with parking.

The restaurant space is pretty tiny.

Met some cousins here, and we so ordered a bunch of dishes -

Steamed chicken
Crab
Steamed Fish
Pork chop
Salted pepper whole shrimp
Beef with bok choy
Eggplant

Everything was pretty standard. 

The bok choy was good (tho I didn't try the beef that it was cooked with).

The crab was fresh, because the crab viscera (the best part!) in the main shell had the consistency that you only see if the crab was fresh.

The salted pepper whole shrimp was breaded and fried with jalapeno's and garlic with the heads intact.  It wasn't bad, though this usually the best if it gets to you sizzling hot. It was warm, but not hot.

The pork chops tasted leftover, twice-fried, overcooked, and dry; then smothered with bottled oyster sauce. Then they gave us a heaping shitload as if they were trying to  get rid of it! I'd say they gave us 2-3 orders (that we didn't ask for!). This was thumbs down.

Eggpant was tasty. Pretty firm, pretty good.

These days, Chinese food is a dime a dozen, and unless it is country/cantonese/home cooking/comfort food that is not on the regular menu, most of it is pretty standard, pretty marginal, and all the same to me. 

I'd only come back to this place if I was meeting my peeps here, but not as my go-to place for Chinese food. 

Not bad, but no wow-factor for me, either. Again, the FRIED PORK CHOPS SUCKED.
author: Jimmy L.

description: I am very unhappy with their food. The food was tasteless and the fish we got was super fishy. So disgusting. I left the restaurant hungry.
author: Stephanie W.

description: Great neighborhood Chinese resturaunt. Salt baked pork chop is outstanding. Just discovered General chicken wings which are hands down awesome. They were hot flavorful and addictive. They do not deliver. Great for take out or eat in.
author: Janet C.

description: For me it has been over a year since I havent had lunch at the Eight Immortals Restaurant until today... Came to this chinese restaurant and had myself one of my favorite steam rice plate which is the Mince Beef W/ Egg Over Steam Rice Yummmmmmy!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! Also I would like to say that this place is not to expensive at all my Mince Beef W/ Egg Over Steam Rice plate that I have ordered to eat for lunch which came to a total of $6.00 in which I had a coca cola with it as well so the total price of my lunch meal wasnt that bad at all!!!
author: William B.

description:
After looking for a local place to eat before going on a long trip I decided to come here. We ordered a bunch of food and got out of there in August. In February I get a call from my credit card that there were charges on there. This is a credit card that I rarely use. 

This was the only place I used my card since my old one expired. So if you had illegal activity on your card and paid with your meal with it here, then it's their staff.
author: M C.

description: I've eaten there for a couple of times now. I always left there with a content mind and a full stomach. Their peking duck is one of their must-order's if you eat duck.  It came with four or five buns, half a duck, and the spicy sauce (DA BOMB). The combination was splendid.
author: Fong C.

description:
I haven't been here in over a decade. Decided to eat here for dinner with my gf. We got in more or less an hour before they closed. It was a Tuesday night and there were some families eating dinner and we got sat right away. 
The decor looked old and dated but I don't think people really come to a Chinese restaurant expecting a modern American restaurant unless its like Koi Palace. This place reminds me of all the other Chinese restaurants from similar items on the menu to the classic black and white look for the waiters and all black attire for the manager. 
We ordered three plates to share - deep fried flounder, two kinds of greens with crab meat (imitation) and chicken with more greens. 
The flounder was huge and moist and I've noticed they do fresh seafood as they have a tank for fish in the kitchen. I assume the flounder was fresh and was tasty. The other two dishes were decent but nothing to rave about. Nothing was dry and stuff came out relatively quick. Amazingly though, their men's bathroom was pretty clean.
Pretty good place for anybody looking for a simple and tasty Chinese meal. Our three entrees came out to just under 26$ which also included some white rice and dessert.
author: Jason L.

description: Super busy spot. Food was good, but damn can you be cramp with how much people are here. Definitely a good spot if you come with someone who is assertive when ordering from the employees.
author: Sonlay V.

description: Today was the first time I cam here for dinner.  I've heard quite a few ppl that said it is good and my old boss use to go there alot.  Portion was extremely small, even thought I've added 1/2 order to some entrees.  Quality/taste either bland or too salty.  Service was very slow, it wasn't completely full and I have to ask for my check three times.  Sadly to say this is my first and last.
author: AB H.

description:
This place is not bad compare with other Chinese restaurant in the Milbrae area. Dinner time are crowed. But it only take like 5 minute to get us a table(not bad).

Saw alot of review saying that, they have a great deal during lunch hour for the Lobster Noodle. I definitely want to stop by at during lunch and get some of that.
author: Joyce W.

description:
This place was a surprise.  I've seen this hole in the wall Chinese when I go for ice cream at Marco Polo next door, but have not gotten the courage to walk in as the place looks a bit like a prison from the outside.  The interior really isn't all that great either as it looks a bit like a funeral parlor.  Since the reviews were fairly positive on Yelp, I thought I order a take out and give it a shot.   It's simple and a bit rustic, but surprisingly the Cantonese  food was quite good for the price.

We ordered a Beef with Snow Peas ($6.50) which was very flavorful.  The beef quality could be a bit better and there could be more beef, but for 6.50 it's hard to complain.  

The Fried Duck($6)  with Taro was also very yummy.  It was perfectly crisp and not greasy at all.  The sauce that came with it went well with the entree.  It's mostly Taro so there could be more duck, but again it was only $6!  So, can't complain here either.  I've had a version of this in a nice Cantonese restaurant in Hong Kong when I was a kid which was phenomenal.  Like most High Chinese dishes, it was labor intensive and involved multiple steps of boiling, deep frying and baking, coating and re-coating (like the real Peking duck).  This obviously is a much humbler version, but tasty non-the-less.

The last item, Pea Shoots with Garlic ($9), was simple but very well stir-fried.  The Pea Shoots were tender which means that they got rid of the not-so-tender parts of the shoot.  Many places keep more of the shoot than they should to increase profits....   

The negative is that there's quite a bit of MSG in their food since they don' t use a lot of meat in the dishes, it's one way to enhance the flavor.  So, if you're tolerance for MSG is low, you may want to skip this place or see if they can make the dishes without MSG. 

I would recommend getting the food to go, unless you're okay with a rather depressing, sparse, windowless environment.  It's definitely worth a drive for their simple Cantonese items.  But remember to stick with Cantonese items (nothing Sichuan or Mandarin!).

4 stars is for the food only.

2 stars for decor and service.
author: Paul K.

description:
I like this place for the most part. I don't know all the names of the dishes because my dad is the one who orders when we've come here or taken out from here. However, the food is decent and the prices are super affordable! Some dishes that my family and I enjoy are:

Filet Of Cod with green vegetables on rice- $3.50 for lunch. They give way too much rice, but the fish is good and the bok choy is nicely cooked (not too mushy).

B.b.q Pork Noodle Soup- $3.00 for lunch. I don't eat pork, so I can't tell you how the pork is; but the broth is pretty flavorful, the noodles are good, and the veggies in the soup are nicely cooked. They give a good amount, too. 

Chinese Style Beef Cubes On Rice- $3.50 for lunch. My dad likes to order this and likes it a lot. He asks for it to be curry style, which they do for him. I'm not sure what that means, but it sounds good.

There was a time that my boyfriend was craving steamed chicken with green onions and garlic/ginger sauce and we ordered it from here. Apparently they didn't know what he was trying to order because they gave us some kind of chicken that was more similar to kung pao chicken. Not a very good experience for my boyfriend. Their chow mein is ok, not the best. The service is good, but they know my dad now, so maybe it is because of that.
