All in all, this is normally the first Chinese place I go to for take out because it is so close to me, but I know there are others in the neighborhood that have some better dishes and better chow mein. If you do come here, come for the prices!! You may just have to try it a few times to decide which dishes are the good ones.
author: Lauren D.

description:
This restaurant has been around for years and had been a family destination until they changed head chefs then the owner. 

Quality of food definitively has gone down. Most if not all regular patrons have moved on to the restaurant on Vicente street (where the old chef and owner now resides). 

Most if not all dishes have been substituted. The black pepper spare-ribs tasted like chocolate ice cream? And the DRY fried fish was smothered in a jalapeno black bean sauce? What is going on? That is not how you substitute an ingredient. You alter the whole integrity of the dish and make it gross. 

I don't think I'll be going back anytime soon. 

No, thank you. I'll pass the next time.
author: Amy C.

description:
Really cheap and really, really good. Most plates cost $5, bottom off at $4.50 & top off around $8 (unless you're getting the abalone).

Definitely one of my top go-to Chinese restaurants even though it's a little far from my house.
author: Angel D.

description: Love their deep fried flounder and salt pepper pook chop.
author: Suwito S.

description: Haven't been to this place in over 6 years and it hasn't changed a bit. My boyfriend and I decided to grab a quick Chinese meal here and was impressed by the quick service, quality of food, and the reasonable prices. Our server was extremely friendly and made an honest effort to ensure we were satisfied with everything. Our food was made in a timely manner and was very tasty. I highly recommend this restaurant for anyone looking for a local Chinese restaurant away from the crowds of Chinatown or Irving street!!!
author: Thao T.

description: this was definitely the go to place for me in High school. Call them and place an order and bam  lunch is served for a great price. Of course now the price has raised but it's still very affordable. When i dont know what im feeling - usually i come here because the staff are always friendly. the food STILL comes in huge portions. and they open kinda late - not like 2am late but late enough for a late dinner.
author: Kristina L.

description:
My family and I really enjoy coming to this restaurant. The staff was very nice and helpful. A few of the dishes we ordered were sold out so our waiter suggested other dishes that were similar to the ones we wanted; he was also very patient as we chose new dishes. 
We ordered fresh steamed fish, noodles, pumpkin and clams, and a vegetable dish. They were all delicious, portioned well, and cheap! After dinner, we were given red bean soup desert, which was also very yummy! My family and I left as happy campers! Definitely coming back!
author: Christy S.

description: nasty place we order sum garlic spinach a fly was there an hair on the rice never again because when you complain they get really mad and want you to pay for the food whit fly and hair no way
author: Valeria F.

description:
This place used to be super cheap and pretty darn good.

Now it's more expensive and just not as good. We always get the taro duck, peking duck, honey walnut shrimp and sweet and sour pork.

But everything was just not as good as when we were younger. Plus I think the portions got smaller... Still not too expensive for the sunset but just average food.
author: Wilson T.

description:
I've been here a couple times and each time, 8 Immortals never fails me. I order the Ying Yang Fried Rice the first time and if you don't know what it is, you HAVE to TRY IT. Its a two tone colored rice where the bottom layer is regular fried rice and it is topped with two different sauces, one sauce made from egg white with shrimp, and the other is a tomato based sauce with chicken. Its layed out to look like a ying yang. 

The second time I came here with my family and we ordered the family deals and I remember loving all the dishes; the fried tilapia, the seafood soup, the crispy skin chicken. 

I came here again yesterday and ordered the Chicken Chien Mien. Its deep fried noodles topped with sauce and chicken and the sauce makes the middle of the noodles soft all while you get that crunch in the corners. I didn't realize there were two different types of chien mien and the one I had yesterday is not the one I usually like, but it was still good. The Minced Chicken Chien Mien only has bean sprouts, green onions, and the meat. The one I typically get has bok choy, mushrooms, chunky meat, and a different sauce, with more flavor.
author: Connie C.

description:
I used to eat here often with my family, but, the quality of the food is not the same. The placement of the tables are exactly how I remember, but, dishes that I used to love now taste bland. 

After expecting so much and leaving somewhat disappointed, I wouldn't return.
author: Juliette R.

description:
Gezzz, one year has gone by and already it's Lunar New Year again! ( To the date precisely! ). Dinner last night was another successful family annual indulgence to close off the years end and to start new beginnings in the year of the Dragon. 

As always during dinner time the crowds are just getting started and many are eager with anticipation. We were fortunately has reserved a large table upstairs as usual with a party of 13. We started with the cold shrimp and sweet fruit lettuce platter, very refreshing. Winter melon soup serve in the whole steamed melon with morsels of pork, baby shrimp, kidney, mushrooms was like my mom's recipe. follow by a barrage of entrees: braised Chinese bacon with fermented greens, steamed fish, braised whole duck stuffed with barley-blackeye peas- chinese acorn nut- chestnut ( very very classic traditional old school dish), pepper fried pork chops, sweet snow peas saute, fried shrimp rice, soy braised squab, whole fried chicken (not too dried), stir fry glaze lobster and  cod -seasnail- welk-clams with mustard greens. Yes, we finish all but a small bit of the stuffed whole duck & chicken.....Till next year.
author: Wolfy W.

description:
I've been here twice and I think I liked the food better the first time.  Anyway, I came here yesterday with a party of 6 and we ordered the $50 set dinner plus two vegetarian dishes for my dad (bill came out to be a little over $80 after tax and tip).  For $50, we had a ton of food:

~ Seafood Soup: meh...it tasted really bland
~ Honey Walnut Shrimp: it was ok...nothing special
~ Steamed Tofu with Shrimp: their tofu was really soft and yummy
~ Conch and Calamari with Chives, Celery and Peas: it only had a few pieces of conch and calamari but the calamari was really soft and tender
~ Lobster with Ginger and Onion: nothing special
~ Clams with Black Bean Sauce: the clams were nice and big and fresh
~ Mustard Greens with Fish Cake: once again, nothing to write home about
~ Fried Catfish with Soy Sauce: best dish of the day...the fish was perfectly crisp and the sauce was great

I've definitely had better Chinese food and probably wouldn't come back for their set dinners. I liked the food better when we ordered from the regular menu last time (but that was more than a year ago so maybe the chef changedt?).
author: Katelynn L.

description: I like the dry chow fun noodle. Snow,pea leaf is really good. Very fast service ,  quantity for your dollar! Take out is good too
author: Matt O.

description:
This is another restaurant I have some childhood memories.  My recollections of 8 Immortals are of home-style Cantonese food and their signature waiter with a permed out fro and big o' eyebrows that grew a half an inch from each side of his face.  He was a funny guy to say the least.    

On that Friday night, I decided to take my family there for old time's sakes since we haven't been here in ages.  When we got there we were seated immediately.  Usually on the busy times, there would be a wait.  Everything seemed the same as usual, but cleaner than what I remember.  

The service was very personable as expected and they took our order pretty fast.  

We ended up ordering something along the lines of this: clams with black bean sauce, oyster clay pot with tofu, deep fried taro duck (not a lot of places have this), and walnut prawns.  Since we have three "rice buckets" in our family, we got white rice.  (Yeah, you saw that right.  There are no vegetables on that list.)  

We ended up eating about half, consequently, leaving a lot of leftovers.  The food was satisfactory.  Much of the dishes were on the salty side (even the walnut prawns seemed salty) or was drenched in its sauce.     

Comparing the food of then and now, the quality hadn't improved, but the prices went up.  This place isn't expensive, but with competition of comparable quality or better in the area, the price tag makes a difference with the focus on their quality.  Back in the day, if one could believe, they used to have some $3 dollar entrees.   

If I were to recommend a Cantonese restaurant, I wouldn't recommend this place.  I would send that person to Ming's Diner.  8 Immortals is cleaner, and the service a tiny bit better than Ming's (depending on your perspective).  When looking for home-style Cantonese food, the food quality/price comparison is advantageous in favor of Ming's Diner.
author: Arnold T.

description:
You know when it's not 1, not 2 but Eight Immortals that there's going to be some good food. This place is low on style and low on cost and it's always good food.

This is a neighborhood place filled with asian folks who live in the neighborhood or who's grandparents do. It has a huge menu as well as the many many signs on the walls and then there are the things they just make when they seem to have surplus of one thing or another.

Whatever you want they probably have. The vegetarian selection is smaller than some other Chinese places and there is mostly seafood. The prices don't seem to have changed in years and the portions are all good.

On my last visit I got the frog and bitter melon claypot that was served piping hot and fresh. The food isn't fancy, the decor is bare bones and I like most of the food I get here. The French spouse like the huge selection of prawn and other seafood dishes.

Also only paying 24 dollars for two entrees and a huge soup for two is pretty sweet.
author: DeathandFood H.

description:
This used to be one of my favorite Chinese spots in the city, back when the interior was funky and the food amazing.  Tonight's dinner was a new low in a long string of occasional visits over the past few years as I kept hoping for a new chef or improvement to their menu.  I won't be going back.  

For about $20 I got two simple dishes.  The first was steamed, shrimp-stuffed tofu.  The shrimp paste had either gone bad, or was a very cheap brand.  It was really fishy tasting -- no shrimp flavor at all.  The sauce was watery and almost flavorless.  The garlic guy lan had almost no garlic in it, and the dish was oily.  The oil would have been OK if it was full of garlic, but oily guy lan is not appealing.

I got a very small bowl of rice packed in with an ice cream scooper, so it wasn't fluffy.  The rounded scoop made eating food on top of it impossible until I ate the plain rice down to a flat surface.  It was too small of a bowl to put food on top of the rice anyway, especially guy lan.  I don't know if they gave me this ridiculous serving because I am not Chinese and they didn't think I'd know better.  I also don't know if I got overcharged because I'm not Chinese; the price was way out of line with the food.  I didn't order off of a menu, and my bill wasn't itemized, so I don't know if they charge that much ordinarily.
author: elsa z.

description:
This place has been here for ages. I remember going to eat here with my family when I was in high school. That was back in the early 1990's. Fast forward to the present. I was visiting my parents and was hankering for some Chinese food. I was flipping through their to go menu pile and spotted this place. I wonder if its still open. Better yet, I wonder if it's still good. I'm a gambling man... Ring ring... 

"Hello 8 Immortals, what would you like?" 
"Wow, I'll call you right back!" 

So I flip through the old menu, reminiscing of the cheaper prices back in the day, looking for some dishes to order. My brother in law is caucasian so I needed to order some Chinese dishes that everyone can enjoy. I picked out:

Crispy Taro Duck - I love taro. I LOVE duck. Naturally these two go hand in hand. They take some taro and place it on top of a slice of duck meat and then lightly batter and deep fry. YUM. It came with a gravy sauce to serve on top. The dish came with about 12 pieces.

Honey Walnut Shrimp - I usually always order this dish when I go to Chinese restaurants. I just love the mayo based sauce on deep fried shrimp. Served with honey walnuts and I'm golden. Dish came with about 15-18 pieces of shrimp.

Beef Chow Fun - Typical beef chow fun. It had good flavor and it wasnt too greasy!

BBQ Pork Fried Rice - Surprisingly good. I usually dont order fried rice since its just left over rice from the day before with egg and meat. Oh, and my dad always yells at me when I do. Haha. This one had a good flavor to it and unlike most places, it was not greasy!

Roast Pork & Oyster Clay Pot - Yum! Another favorite dish of mine. Roast pork. Oysters. Tofu. Chinese Mushrooms. Tons of gravy so it goes soooo good with rice.

Beef and Tofu - The staple dish for my niece. She loves tofu. LOVES. This dish was pretty good for being simple. I liked it.

The best part of the meal? When I went to pick up the food, I also grabbed a new to go menu. WOWSERS. The price probably went up like 50 cents to a $1 for each dish. Not bad considering how old the menu I had was. Still honey walnut shrimp for $8 is NOT BAD AT ALL!

I also posted some mouth watering pictures. Seriously, if you dont get hungry looking at the pictures I posted... You need to delete your yelp account now and log on to www.amitheonlyweirdonehere.com !!!!

Disclaimer: Yes, I just made up that website. There's nothing there. Dont cry.
author: Leo C.

description: Has good food and nice service. The food usually comes out pretty quickly and hot. I like that they give a pot of rice and not just separate small bowls of rice. I also like the happy hour specials they have.
author: Lawrence Y.

description:
Great food!! Great prices!! And it's pretty clean inside.

Inca Kola - The Golden Carbonated Beverage
http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/1BvSPcVjivynLv_Bq-UzHw/l

Our Dishes
http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/d1spH_R9Bxny7YLkHDbw3A/l

(Saturday, March 7, 2009)
author: Kenny C.

description:
Damn, i love cheap but good chinese food. when it comes to joints like this, who cares about the service? well whenever i'm at a chinese restaurant, i dont even bother thinking about service cuz they usually dont have any sense of good customer service.

Anyways, for lunch, they have a special of chosing three entrees for only 19.99 and it comes with rice and a huge bowl of soup for the party. It was a party of 4 this one day we ordered a black bean rock cod, black bean string beans, and a salted fish and chicken egg plant sizzling pot. 

that was a lot of food for 4 people and we just got lucky and finished all of the entrees so we wouldnt have to take food home. food was really good. not too salty or anything and the egg plant was cooked really nicely. they use a lot of bell peppers and onions in the black bean dishes but i sure didnt mind. 

lunch came out to about $25 with tip for four people. A-mazing.
author: Kenny L.

description:
I hate to admit it, but my son and I kind of got the gwai-lo treatment here. I say I hate to admit it because it's rarely happened to me personally. I take a little bit of pride in being a long-time SF resident who understands that levels of service at restaurants in such a diverse place are naturally, culturally different. Which is to say that we're super patient and always ready to offer (or accept) an excuse for slow or virtually non-existant service. I say this also as someone who has worked and cooked at restaurants in the past. I'm patient. 

But we clearly weren't their ideal customer. We were the only non-Chinese folks here for lunch on a Sunday, and it took us forever to get a menu or an order placed. And then it took eons to get our food made and sent to our table. We sat and watched people (who were still waiting in line for a table after we ordered) get sat, order, eat, and get their check before we even got a set of chopsticks and a cup of tea and a menu -- much less an order placed. (And then they gave us forks when we asked for chopsticks. Of course.) 

It was unwelcoming, to say the least. We stuck it out as a matter of principle, but we may not go back. Food is decent, though, with a few standout dishes, but it's not awesome overall. They eschew condiments on their tables, which saddens me. The flavors are mostly on the tame side.
author: Casey C.

description:
My friend from the Richmond District decided to bring me to Eight Immortals. The restaurant is understated with no windows to look into so it is very easy to miss if you are unfamiliar with the area. Upon entering, you can see a small but busy place with a lot of families eating there. The place is very good for family style dining and the atmosphere is warm and it makes you feel like home.

The food there is simply outstanding. The pea sprout leaves are a must. They also specialize in oysters which were fresh and tasty. I thought the two versions of Chicken with ginger and scallion were both delicious; with the Chinese style chicken less meaty but has a more flavor with every bite. I thought the combination seafood with bean curd clay pot was a bit overwhelmed with bean curd, but the sweet and sour beef steak cube was nice and tender. The quality of the food sets the standard for good Cantonese cuisine, enough for me to travel out of my way into the neighborhood. 

The dishes I would not recommend are the roast duck and the double mushroom with bok choy. The duck was too dry and too skinny for my taste and the bok choy we had was old, not fresh. The honey walnut shrimp was good and on the sweet side, but I've had better elsewhere. But overall, this place keeps it down to earth and has yield great results. The atmosphere and food quality is fitting for large and small family gatherings, a good place to introduce your parent(s) to your new girl/boy friend, and your closest friends who don't need the fancy decors to be impressed.

I wish there's an exciting dessert place on Taraval to visit after the meal. I'm a big fan of Eight Immortals and my friend from the Richmond District has finally put us back on the right track. For cultural authenticity, taste, freshness, this place deserves a five star rating. However, I'm giving it a 4 star since the food was a bit inconsistent on my third visit. More importantly, the restaurant did not live up to its billings as a "seafood restaurant" for its unremarkable clay pot and honey walnut shrimp.
author: Daniel L.

description:
This is totally our family's go to spot for inexpensive, delicious chinese food!

We do our usual--honey walnut shrimp, fried fish, beef + bok-choy, the occassional crab and shark-fin soup. We were there a few weeks ago (for dinner with some family friends) and totally did the whole $200 family meal. Super good. There were some dishes there that I've never tried before and we've been eating at this place for years! The fried taro and fu-kin chow fun was DA BOMB! Can't stress that enough--yum yum. Next time you're there, GET THAT. You won't regret it.
author: Lily W.

description:
Sunday nite and we made reservations for a party of 17 at 8 Immortals.  My friend Jay and I went to 8 immortals for lunch all the time.  Jay really enjoyed chowfun and we never went to dinner.  I know why!  The dinner service SUCKED big time.  The staff delivers the food quickly and tasty.  Other amenities - tea refill, forks, etc.   We had to get our own chopsticks, extra bowls, and everything because they are understaffed or simply can't handle the business.  
Typical Lousy Chinese Restaurant Service - not enough people and too many customers.
author: Aprams C.

description:
I haven't been here for a couple of years and I've enjoyed it this place very much in the past. I came here recently with a couple of friends and it wasn't how I remembered it.
We ordered the following:

Fried Deep Fried Squid: Decent, good portion, and mild seasoning.

Mandarin Dinner for 3;
Hot and Sour Soup: Good, not to spicy or sour, almost 2 servings per person, recommended

Fried Prawn: Alright, it was a bit on the salty side but the sauce balanced it out. Definitely would order the Spicy Salt and Pepper shrimp over this.

Mongolian Beef: Alright, kind of on the salty side, good if you have steamed rice but doesn't go too well with the fried rice.

Shrimp in Lobster sauce: Didn't touch it, it looked like shrimp and egg goop. Not very appetizing. 

Yang Chow Fried Rice: Good, not too salty and I thought it was prepared very well. Lots of meat and good amount of seasoning.

Lemon Chicken: It looked and tasted more like honey-lemon chicken. Sour initial taste then the sweetness kicks in. It's not too bad but I could only eat so much before the sugar got to me.

In addition to the Mandarin Dinner:

Clam in Black Bean Sauce: Very Good, this was probably my favorite out of all the things we ordered. Clams were cooked almost to perfection and the sauce was not too overpowering. Definitely recommended.

Sauteed Fresh Oyster with Ginger & Green Onions: This would have been delicious if I hadn't eaten 20 oysters this past weekend. It was overall pretty good, enough seasoning to compliment the oyster but not enough to overpower it. We did ask for some lemons to add a little bit of zest to it. Recommended, for about 1 dollar an oyster (We got 6 total).


Overall, the food was good. I would definitely skip out on the pre-selected dinner and order dish by dish. Our total overall was 56 dollars without tip. Service was okay, our waitress was definitely nicer than our waiter.
author: Chris T.

description:
This place used to be good. I heard they changed owners so I figured.

Anything associated with the word IMMORTALS should be nothing short of just that. Since this restaurant is named so,  it SHOULD be a excellent restaurant.

Went today with my frd and ordered 3 dishes. The place only had 4 tables open so its not like they are busy.

They only had 1 chef working today, or maybe just really slow ones. The 3 dishes we ordered came out 10 minutes apart so its like a tease.

The portion of the dishes was really really small. It we had more than 2 person, we wouldnt be full. 

No complimentary soup or dessert/orange/fortune cookie?

Wont be coming back for awhile. Wished the old owner would take away the "8 IMMORTALS" name so its old reputation wouldn't be ruin.
author: U L.

description:
The crab was only $20 bucks!  Holy crap!  However, it wasn't as great as the ones I've had at R&G and PPQ for almost $40 (go figure).  The price tag makes it worth coming here for the crab.

Bf and I also had the walnut shrimp and the fried tofu.  Both were very standard dishes and weren't bad.

I like the service here too.  The waiters and waitresses are friendly, unlike at other lower end Chinese restaurants.

The bathrooms are clean too!  And they are not stingy with the napkins.

Did I mention that the crab was only 20 bucks??
author: Vivian H.

description:
Sunset is definately turning into the place to find great tasting authentic chinese food that's not getting the panda express treatment. Chinatown is for tourists. 8 Immortals never fails to meet my expectations. The seafood is as fresh as it gets and the flavors are an explosion in my mouth.

Try: clams, salt and pepper crab, lobster, shrimp
author: Vicky L.

description:
What I've learned over the years while living in San Francisco is that to truly appreciate Chinese food, you must first accept their, mediocre if any, service. With that being said, Eight Immortals may be one of the very few Chinese restaurants in SF that actually serves deliciously authentic cuisine with the kind of service you can expect from any gross Chinese or Asian restaurant given my statement above. 

What to order:
Their famous chicken with Chinese cucumber, bell pepper, green onion, and a hypnotizing medley of spices
Garlic spinach

Yes...that's it. Order those two things with steamed rice and your choice of fish and soup and you are good to go! Believe me, I'm not a regular at this place for nothin'.

Eight Immortals stands strong and probably always will, as my favorite local Chinese restaurant.
author: Jasmin W.

description:
8 immortals left me with a mortal wound. The stir fry pea shoots had extra "green" sauce in the oil. The bean curd dish was on the sour side.

Why did I come here in the first place, you ask? Because I was craving for some Marco Polo Italian ice cream (next door) but was also starving for some dinner. At least I went home with 4 pints of DELICIOUS ice cream in a variety of flavors: canteloupe, guava, strawberry and lychee from Marco Polo.
author: Helen Y.

description:
Prices are cheap,so don't expect for them to waiting on you hand & foot! Also,if you try to eat here on Friday,Saturday,or Sunday nights,prepare to
stand in line and wait one hour or more.Yeah! It's that popular with the local sunset neighborhood.The food is well prepared & maybe a little on the bland side,but all you have to do is season your food to your liking.As far as the "old man and old lady", sure they move slow.Why? Because they don't have to move for anyone.They own the joint. If you don't like it then go elsewhere.
These folks have enough business to last them 10 lifetimes!

Update 1-21-11 The "old people" are gone! They retired & sold the place!
No worries.I spoke to the new owner and she doesn't intend to change
the old food recipes.She also retained the original staff.Try it out!
author: Buddha B.

description:
good cheap ''authentic'' Cantonese food in the Bay Area.
the fresh oysters in soy sauce with green onions and ginger was really good. the Spicy Green Beans were not dry enough though.. and afterwards the msg really kicked in.

the staff is really friendly, especially when I busted out my Cantonese. I looked around and it seems like everyone ordered the Fried Porkchops and a plate of jellyfish ... so next time I know what to order! 

this place gets packed fast so get there early, but good thing their turnaround is quick!
author: Lauren Y.

description:
I actually eat here by accident.  I was volunteering and my friend say this place has very cheap and good food.  WOW!  The "tea time" items are only $2 each and some drinks are only $1.  The size of the plates are not small at all.  But the glasses are very very sticky, which i think it's nasty.  The drink was okay though, a little too sweet for me.  Good place for cheap and good food.  

Will definitely come back again, except it's way too far from my house.
author: Lily L.

description:
Sad Update: Shortly after I posted my sparkling review, this place took a nose dive. Every time I got food there, the bf and I would notice how the portions looked smaller, the ingredient quality was lower, and there was less and less meat. In looking at other Yelp reviews, it seems that there was a change of ownership.

We were given the wrong order so many times that I started checking every single container before I left the place, which the dragon lady owner very obviously did not appreciate. One time, she sent 3 orders of spinach instead of 3 orders of snow peas and scallops -- hello, that's a $15 difference, and she refused to acknowledge or make up for that mistake over the phone. 

We've stopped going there. I can eat crappy Chinese food at one of those Chinese/Donut combo places (hah, ewwww). Really a shame, as I was so excited to have discovered them.
author: debbie r.

description:
When you get past the indecency of tables left unclean with dishes and leftover food parcels everywhere (which you might witness upon stepping through the door), you will find that the food served here changes your opinions about this place. Don't always judge a restaurant's food by the way the restaurant appears.

The food is good stuff! I've been coming here pretty often as a child. After having not visited for a number of years, the food remains as delicious as I can remember.  

My favorite dish ever: Fish fillet in corn cream sauce-- fried fish fillets, then dressed with a corn starch sauce made of corn kernels, egg, and starch. 

Other dishes that you can't go wrong with: 
Sauteed veggies, steamed whole fish, tofu with shrimp. 

Don't mind the service either. Food gets solid 4 stars.
author: Karen W.

description:
I had some seafood noodle thing, and it smelt HORRIBLE and felt slimy. But it was like what, under $5? I can't complain. They don't really deserve a 4 star rating, but then again, they don't deserve a 3. 3 1/2?

They offer discounts to students on weekdays, and they staff is pretty nice. Their plates are definitely cheap and huge (This is the first place I've ever eaten an egg-foo-yung) and it's like all other Chinese restaurants - greasy, oily, quick, and comforting.

Their service isn't perfect, but on my recent visits to this restaurant, it has been outstanding! I've come on slow weeknights lately, so that may be it, so hint to all of you: come on slow weeknights, and be polite to the servers - I do believe that they have tempers - and if you speak Chinese, major props to you.
author: Colleen M.

description:
8 Immortals! This is the cheapest Chinese Restaurant I've ever been to. Cheap in a GOOD WAY! For its price, the food is good and the place is decent!
Some of our fave here are:
-Porridge (happy hour price is $2)
-Fried Fish (flounder/sole fish, suace on the side)
-Peking Duck with Steamed Buns
-Crispy/Fried Noodles with Mixed Seafood
author: kat s.

description:
Good, cheap Chinese food that is solid and hearty.  You'll find ample amounts of Chinese broccoli with tender beef at this Cantonese restaurant.  The black bean chicken and honey walnut shrimp are okay, but the orange-flavored fried pork chops, which is a special not on the menu, seem to be a local fave.  For $8, you can get one of the best pan-fried flounders, which is a great deal.  The oysters with black bean sauce look humungous, but it's hard to taste the fresh flavors of the sea.  

If you can't afford to wait for a table, grab some take out and don't miss the opportunity to get dessert at Marco Polo next door when you're done.
author: Jenny L.

description:
Ehh...It was a lot better a couple of years ago.  Now they raised their prices and the portions shrank ( That's a no-no.  You either do one or the other.  How dare you do both!).  

We stopped going last year when they changed their policy of providing a big container of rice for 80 cents/person and made everyone buy one bowl of rice for $1 each.  You know when they had the container, it's all you can eat rice but w/ one bowl, if you're done, then you'd have to order another one for $1.  Boo hiss re that policy!

Food is ok.  We used to get the $90+ menu (which I understand doesn't exist anymore since they raised the prices).  One thing I couldn't stand was the scallops wrapped in fried taro.  Reminded me of a little drum.  Once you down that sucker, you're too full to eat anything else (a bad thing considering you ordered the set seafood menus).
author: Wendy H.

description: Stay away! This place is scary. I've had better Americanized Chinese food at a mall in the midwest. Dirty, disgusting, crossing my fingers that I haven't been poisoned.  Hot and sour soup was bland and smelled like dish soap, mongolian beef was slimy and rubbery, took one bite of the prawns with lobster sauce and was ready to run for my life. Fried rice had to have been days old, and I got the most depressing fortune cookie when the bill arrived. I'm honestly pretty easy to please, especially when I'm really hungry, but I wanted to ask for my fucking money back. I think the "8 Immortals" are the last remaining customers that haven't died after eating here.
author: Becky M.

description: I been coming here for 3 years and I recently just found a hair in my egg beef rice. I asked for a refund since I didn't eat much and I lost my appetite and they wanted me to wait till everybody leaves. once everyone left, i asked for my money back since i barly touched my food. the owner then said, "no refund, ill make you a new one". what?..... how do they expect me to eat their food after taking a bite and finding hair in my first plate. Never coming back again.
author: Jack L.

description:
I came here today to visit my old stomping ground.  It has been years since I have been to 8 immortals.  I used to work across the street and this was my go to place for lunch.. Fast, Friendly, and Good.

The reason why this place is good is because everything is well seasoned.  You know the wok that they used is seasoned, the workers are seasoned, the owners are seasoned.  The just do a great job from the back of the house to the front of the house.

Just like i remembered..............always a solid restaurant.

Notable items:

Believe it or not, I Love their Chicken Salad here.  I think they make it the best.  You would never guess that a Chinese restaurant would be able to make a good Chinese chicken salad.

Any of the Chow mein and chow fun are excellent.  It has that definitive "wok hay"  where you know these chefs are seasoned pros.

Their Fried Tofu with the fish cake on top is awesome.  It's fried to perfection and the tofu is still silky smooth in texture.

I have had their whole set menu before and everything is solid.  I just had the three items today.  Will come back if I ever make it out here again.
author: jason g.

description:
I came here quite a lot many many years ago and just recently returned to try eating here again. I was surprised that things changed :(
The food here are still excellent just like many years ago.
What I meant by the changes were that, back then, in order to get a table, we had to wait even half an hour. Now, quite empty :( Where did all the patrons go?
Ah, after reading the reviews from others, apparently, some patrons rather go to River Side instead.
And ah yes, I've tried River Side. The food was excellent, no complaint about it, but the price is way above Eight Immortals for similar taste.

Hm, about the health score. Well, so far, I have not been sick :)
Basically, all restaurants have their dirty sides. It's just a matter of whether they get caught during the sudden health inspection or not.
I worked at American restaurant before so I know :)
They would clean and tidy up when they hear rumors that inspector would be coming that day. Otherwise, I even saw a manager pick up fallen food and put it back to serve. I still have many horror stories I experienced when I worked at another famous steak house.

If you want it clean, cook your food yourself at home :)
author: H M.

description:
Hubby wanted the Hung Tao Yee won ton soup, $6, again and it's hard to find many restaurants in the city where this is on the menu.  I decided to try the chicken and salty fish fried rice, $6.  It was pretty authentic, if not too salty.  The place was packed with people at the weekend lunch hour and they seem to do well with take out.  This guy came in and carried out 2 bags of food, looked like he had 8 take out boxes or more in his bag.  Got an order of raw egg over minced beef over rice for Jr. Yelper who enjoyed it as well.  They give you larger portions that 2 persons will only need 2 dishes but with such an extensive menu, it's hard to to resist trying more.  From 11AM-5PM, they have a special menu with 138 items where you select 3 items for $20 and it comes with the house soup and rice!  Additionally, happy hour is 2-5PM wth 32 items for a mere $2 each as well as 5 drinks (milk tea, lemon tea, ice red bean, honey tea). A bargain for good tasting food.

The next day, we went back for more but did take-out.  The beef, pepper, blk bean sauce ho fun was oily, the noodles were smothered in gravy.  Ick.  It tasted OK.  Hubby's beef chow mein was better.  Obviously some hit or miss dishes but with such a huge menu, it's worth repeat visits to try more.
author: Ry T.

description:
Came here on a whim with family. Should've eaten next door at Ninki's instead. 

While the food was mediocre, the service was piss poor. I do mind seating myself, but at least acknowledge me as a customer! Meet & greet? They could seriously put in some effort into customer service. 

Ordered sweet & sour pork with brown sauce - was okay but lathered with too much sodium-induced sauce. 

The deep-fried fish that we ordered was teeny tiny. While I personally do not eat fish, my mom at least enjoyed it. Plus one for that despite the size of it. 

The green beans w/ minced chicken was okay. Not great, but not bad. Nothing really special about it that made it memorable.

Overall, they can really put some more effort into customer service. I shouldn't have to flag the same waiter/waitress 2-3x in order to get my teapot refilled. I know they see me, but to have the audacity to purposely ignore me and not say a word? I should have taken my business and my money elsewhere. 

This place would be good if you're a hungry & broke high schooler. If you want decent food with an acceptable customer service level, go elsewhere. Go next door!
author: Killah K.

description:
I would give this place no stars if i could. Awful food, awful service, everything from tables to walls were dirty. Food was mediocre at best when it wasn't burnt. Walking by the kitchen there is the smell of a dirty cat litter box. 
This place ruined our mothers day family dinner with an awful expearence even though it was pretty empty. 
Will never go back here. So much for new ownership making this place good for something other than high school students cheap lunch. I wouldn't eat here again no matter how cheap it was
author: Laura B.

description:
New owner meant new chef.  My family used to go here as long as I remembered but stopped going one year.  Years later, we're back!  I'm finding out now, as an adult, that apparently my fam didn't like the quality of the food.

We ordered a bunch of food and what stood out in a negative way was their salt and pepper pork.  Flavorless and soggy.  Their walnut prawn dish was sad looking with no creatively put into presentation.  The fried rice was delicious and so was the pork belly dish.  Everything else was just mediocre.  

Whether or not we'll be back is entirely up to the fam again.
author: Rosalind S.

description: i ordered walnut prawn, rod cod clay pot, crispy rice seafood soup, and escargot. Loved the crispy rice seafood soup, walnut prawn was ok. didnt really eat the rod clay pot, wasnt that interested in it.
author: Linda A.

description: I've been here when the old owners were around and i'm still back. I come here for the steamed fish. Simple flavors are the best! Even my grandfather comes here for his birthday, it must be good!
author: Thomas C.

description:
I used to come here a lot for family dinners and whatnot. I haven't been here for years, but my Aunt brought my family here for afternoon tea time. That's the time when the prices are lowered and you can get certain dishes at a cheaper price. Although it might seem like a small portion, it's only two bucks for some appetizers.

FOOD: 
1. Fried squid covered in pepper and salt
2. Macaroni in chicken broth + pork
3. Cold Hong Kong style lemon tea

I love the fried squid! The macaroni was alright, but I can't complain for the price of it. And the lemon tea only cost $1.00!!! Amazing. Other restaurants would charge $2.50-$3.95 for the same drink. Not alot of people know about the afternoon tea special because they don't advertise it. But it's definitely a good find.
author: Desmond C.

description:
I remember coming here everyday except Tuesday during my sophomore year. If you go to Lincoln, you know that you HAVE to call in right when lunch starts or else you'll be waiting an extra 20-30 min on top of the 15 minute walk down the hill & up the hill.

Anyways the man who works up front is a really nice guy!! Always friendly no matter how many people were there. The prices here are very reasonable, especially during lunch time!! Most things only cost about $5.

I am a huge fan of their pan fried noodles with beef & tomato, beef chow fun, and beef stew over rice. What can I say? I LOVE MY MEAT!
author: Erica A.

description:
Okay my family has been going to the 8 immortals Restuarant for years! my dad has a liqour store and  he used to supply inca cola (a peruvian soft drink) to the 8 immortals so you would imagine when we go eat there we get nice service or even table.....wrong!!!!!!!!

I mean the food is good i will not argue that,its good. But the service is HORRIBLE! i wish i can turn to a spoiled rich sunset disrict chinese girl  with big knockers for 2 hours so i can get a table or a waiter/waitress that doesnt give me the stink eye when i order (when they show up after 30-40 minutes later afet we get seated) 

the old guy that runs the register or the old lady are like chairman mao and hitler had a love child and made them work at 8 immortals they run that place like chinese prison mess hall. bad service i vow never to go back, NEVER!!!!!! i dont care how good there roasted duck is! 
my parents still go there and i swear they must love to be treated like crap. awful.
author: Alex P.

description: Ehhh I didn't enjoy the food here. The food was just an okay for me, and I don't think I'll be in a rush to come back here.
author: Song Z.

description:
Where's grandma and grandpa?  Did ownership change?  My family and I have been coming here for two decades and it's usually pretty good.  But we recently stopped by for take out and the orange chicken is hard and chewy, not suitable for kids.  Clams with satay sauce went up in price months ago, salt and pepper pork chop is a bit soggy, chow fun with blackbean sauce no longer have veggies.  WHAT HAPPENED!!

They now have a new menu with dim sum and also specials from 2-5PM which is inexpensive.  I haven't stopped by since our last take out disaster ...
author: Yun C.

description:
I've been eating here ever since I was a child.  When we have a big Chinese family dinner, be it Chinese New Years, Moon Festival, grandpa's birthday, or just a Chinese dinner with the family, Eight Immortals is our choice very often.  The owner of the restaurant and the lead lady are very nice. Prices are reasonable.  The inside is like your typical Chinese restaurants where the big tables always have lazy Susans on them, nothing super fancy, but it is a a clean restaurant.

The food's great!  I've never had a problem with their food.  The taste of authentic traditional, Chinese cuisine.  Whenever I'm there, I always have to order their Orange Porkchops! They're so tasty, delicious and addicting!  I also love the sweet and sour pork, mmm my fave.

I haven't been here in a while, and it's past due. I'll be there soon!  See you at Eight Immortals!
author: Elizabeth Y.

description:
Last month I got some food to go for dinner, it was a special combination that was a lot of food for like $8. It included bbq pork fried rice, sweet & sour pork, and mongolian beef. It may have also included an egg roll.

None of it was good, and to make the experience worse I was rushed into ordering by the woman working there. If I try Eight Immortals again I will order something a la carte instead of going for a special, but there are tons of other Chinese restaurants in the area that I will try first.
author: Joseph N.

description:
Been coming for over 20 years... and through changes in ownership (I think)... food is still great although lately i've noticed that their food isn't as sharp and tasty as it once was.  Still good but not great... perhaps I'm older and more discriminating, but their service and cleanliness is somewhat lacking though for the food and service compared to many other restaurants, it isn't bad... just not great.  

Anyways I'll still keep coming when the family still wants to have dinner here.
author: Helicon K.

description: Pretty good Chinese food. Came here for my boyfriend's grandpa's bday dinner. Upstair private rooms.
author: Amy C.

description: Came here for dinner on Christmas (what else are a couple of Jews to do?) The wait wasn't too long, HOWEVER the food is not worth what they charge for it. Was pretty disappointed. One of our dishes had whole pieces of shell in it. When we pointed it out to our server and to whom I assume was the manager all we got was a shrug and half-hearted apology. I don't think I'll be coming back.
author: Mary M.

description:
CHEAP AND DELICIOUS!!!

My friend and I are always in search of some cheap eats and that's basically why we hang out. He's told me about this place numerous times and I've been trying to find a Chinese restaurant that I actually like in the city. 

Eight Immortals is it. 5 plates of food for $20 WHAT?!! Yes, the place is a little cramped, but $20 I don't really care.

Fried Wontons.
Salt and Pepper porkchops
shrimp fried rice
combination chow mein
pork dumplings.

after 2 full friends eat their little hearts out. We still had left overs! I think I won rock, paper, scissors and took it home =)
author: J B.

description:
So I might be not be giving this place a fair chance since I didn't try their food, but the way they treated us was completely unacceptable.
I went in with my family and a few friends, about 8 of us, and we let them know, it takes about 15 minutes for us to get seated, it was fairly busy in there, so that was to be expected. 
Then after we got seated, we were left unattended for about another 10 minutes, not even given a menu. We wanted to use this time to at least decide what to order, so my friend walked over to one of the staff to get some menus, but he was rudely told to go sit down and wasn't handed anything. About 10 minutes later, they finally come along and hand us some menus. We took a few minutes to decide on our order and try to wave down a waiter, no luck. Another 15 minutes or so past as we are blatantly ignored and we had enough so we got up and walked out. Even if we were able to have our orders taken at that time, god knows how long it would've took for the food to actually come out.

In short, it should not take almost 40 minutes after seating a customer to take their order, much less even give them a menu. Will never come here again.
author: Chris N.

description:
8 Immortals brings fond memories with my family, so it always has a place with me. Oh the food isn't bad either! =P

I've been coming here since middle school with my family, and we always order 12-16 plates on average for just 5 people. Typically we order shrimp in walnut(one of the best I've had), clams with black bean sauce, oysters, fried tofu with shrimp, steamed tofu with shrimp, all sorts of vegetables, flounder, sweet and sour pork, some rice plate with tomatoes, crispy taro duck, beef chow fun, etc etc.

I must say, their food is above average and the prices are good as well. The restaurant has two floors of seating, but the second floor is open only when the bottom floor gets too crowded. Food is speedy, waiters are attentive because we know them, otherwise just shout out, it is a Chinese restaurant after all!
author: Austin N.

description:
Eight Immortals Restaurant definitely filled the stomach of 24 hungry mortals... and then some! BURP!

It's simple Chinese food that is cheap, authentic, tasty, served in big portions and just all round fantastic, in a "hole in the wall" setting... of course, you DO need a tourist VISA to get to the Outer Sunset! KIDDING!

Headed here this past Friday with a group of 24 hungry mortals to celebrate our friend's graduation from culinary school (YAY!) and we decided to do a family style group dinner.

The group menu included:
1. Wonton Soup
2. Egg Roll
4. Sweet & Sour Pork
5. Beef with Oyster Sauce
6. BBQ Pork Fried Rice
7. Roast Duck
8. Cashew Nut Chicken
9. House Pork Spare Ribs

Food tasted good and authentic (the fat in the Roast Duck I have now deemed the Asian version of American Bacon... ANYTHING will taste good with fat from Roast Duck sitting in it!), the place was clean, service was your a-typical Asian style at its best - curt, quick, efficient and no-nonsense... almost drill like. HAI! HYAAH!

Like chatty-Kathy's at an all-gay Bingo game hosted by the Sisters, this motley crew dug in and dove in like a group of barbaric Mongolians who had not eaten in days.. well, 5 hours for most, but whose counting!?

And the bill at the end for 24 stuffed, in food coma, keeling over, belt loosening, pant unbuttoning, tooth picking mortals ? About $440 for the entire group or about $18 per person... not too shabby, I'll say.

P.S. Do NOT attempt to put your seat belt on post meal... its embarrassing! Take the L Muni line which gets you downtown in minutes.
author: Amit S.

description:
I order take-out from here 1-2 times a week.  Yummy food (haven't ordered a dish I haven't liked yet), inexpensive (~$5 for many dishes), and fast service (10-15 min for take-out).  I've dined in several times, and the service has been good.

My favorite is Honey Walnut Prawns (serving size isn't as large as most other dishes, but they make this dish well IMO).  I also regularly enjoy the basics, like Beef/Chicken with Broccoli, Cashew Nut Chicken, etc.

Definitely a go-to place for me.
author: Thuan N.

description:
This Chinese restaurant taste average. the only thing that good is the price. very cheap! i forget what i order because i order too much last time.

CONCLUSION = NOT RECOMMENDED!
author: Aris L.

description: I found a caterpillar cooked into my fried rice.  Enough said.  :(
author: Stacey C.

description:
OMG, I finally met the Eight Immortals!!!

I had the crispy taro duck, clams with black bean sauce, and claypot chicken with ginger and onion. All of them are good, not fly-me-to-the-moon kinda food, but will definitely come back. The clams are really fresh. Next time, I might order more seafood :D 

The service was pretty good. Don't come here during school recces s time, it'll be so packed by high school students.
author: Marlis T.

description:
Your typical Local Chinese seafood restaurant.  They used to have all these dishes for $3.50 when there was a price war a few years back. Now they've finally adjusted to inflation, but prices are still very reasonable.  It beats cooking after a long day at work.  Majority of the dishes are good, but there are some bad ones...

Favorite choice for big parties -- the family dinners are reasonable and good.  They get really busy at night, advanced reservations is highly recommended.  Understaffed so service is not the best during busy nights. Upstairs dining area might be illegal - small cramped space and no air vents.
author: Jannie Q.

description:
The only reason they don't get one star is that they weren't overtly rude. We waited 10 minutes for a table, ok, that happens, but there were several open. Then, it took forever to even place our order. (15 more mins)  The help could be seen, but avoided us. Just when I was ready to leave, they arrived and we ordered the black-pepper ribs, walnut prawns, lemon chicken. and taro duck. The ribs were fine. I've never had them before so I won't ding them (soggy and fatty) and I liked the sauce. The walnut prawns were not. The walnuts were obviously stale and the serving size small. The lemon chicken "looked" good, but it was dry, and obviously over-cooked. The duck? It flew the coop, and, to be honest, we'd forgotten about it until they told us they were out. Problem was. We were close to finishing our meal. Of course, they left it on the bill.

I should have re-read the reviews before going. I bookmarked this place some time ago based on earlier reviews and it looks like ownership has changed since. I noticed several reviews mentioning how cheap the prices are. I didn't see that. The prices are comparable with other  restaurants with the same, but better quality, menu.
author: Rich M.

description: I had to update this just to mention their walnut prawns and salt and pepper ribs are delicious. Also, to clarify--it's called Sizzling Rice Seafood Soup.
author: Catherine M.

description: Like this place a lot...I think this place is one of the best Chinese restaurants in the Sunset.  Been going here on and off for years now and their service & food is off the hook!!  I would say that I haven't had a bad dish served at this place...yet.  Even their chow mein is really good and I don't even eat chow mein much!!  Though one take-out dish I always get and is super good...their onion pork chop over rice!!  Priced reasonably...but the only thing is that they have long waits sometimes and it could be pretty difficult to find parking their during busy times.
author: Patrick C.

description:
Went to eat here with my friends today and I have to say, don't judge a book by its cover!!! We came just in time at 2pm for their happy hour lunch specials

We ordered:
-Shredded Pork & Eggplant Lunch special (good)
-Shrimp fried rice   (okay)
-Shrimp Tomato something rice (good)
-Salt&Pepper Squid (Good) - only 2 bucks!
-Fried Bananas (Good)
-Bok Choy (decent)

With the prices ranging from 4.50 to 7 bucks for a lunch dish and 2 bucks per happy hour lunch special, I don't think you can find a better place that will offer the same bang per buck

love this place. would come again. solid 4/5 for a less than 10 dollar per person chinese food restaurant.
author: Joey L.

description:
OK moving from NY, I really had to get used to the different Chinese food here. Yes, Chinese is different on the west coast. Not worse, not better, just different. I found Eight Immortals as its a few blocks from me and it is great! The food is super yum yum! Egg Fried rice is dope! The Sesame Chicken and Shrimp with Lobster sauce are some of my favs.
On a side note, one thing I miss from NYC was General Tso's chicken. I know this was made for the hungry American as there was probably never an actual General Tso in the Chinese army but still, how come some entrepreneur didn't make it out here with it? :-) Ok I am done with my General Tso rant  oh and I miss the egg rolls from NYC too!
author: Jeff M.

description:
I miss high school. Memory #45287: ordering lunch to-go from Eight Immortals.

You can't turn down the great valve of their lunch plate specials, pricing between $4-7 (depending on what you order). Students get a special discount, which I believe is a dollar off of the lunch plate's marketed price so it's a really, really good deal! I typically go for the (wet) pan fried noodles with beef, also known as "Flat Rice Noodle with Beef in Special Flavor Soy Sauce" on their menu. But if I'm fiending for a rice dish, I always go for the minced Beef with egg on rice. The egg is perfect everytime.

Mmmm, I want to order lunch from there very soon. The food can be oily, but it's such a delicious (chinese food) indulgence. Portions are huge, too!
author: Annie S.

description:
My high school friends decided to pick this place to come for lunch on Sunday since it brought back memories of the good ol days.  Problem was, I don't ever recall coming here when I was in high school.  I must've not been invited.

Anyhow, we came here and had a nice simple meal.  The inside is rather small and it fits the description of a nice clean small chinese restaurant.  Im sure the people who come here are locals and long time loyal customers.  Between the 6 of us, we ordered up a storm and only paid about $11 each.  
-Taro Duck - plenty of taro, not so plenty duck....it was ok.

-Pan Fried Noodles - really greasy but love the tasty msg flavor

-Shrimp and egg over flat rice noodles - this dish has been my backup dish for all chinese restaurants, you can't go wrong with it, just like here.

-Peking Pork Ribs - pretty good, nothing spectacular

-Walnut Prawns - I dont' know if its because it got cold, but the shrimp was rather soggy and small.  

I guess overall, don't expect too much, but you won't leave feeling dissaopinted.
author: Vincent K.

description:
Eight Immortals was a great restaurant....over 20 years ago.  One of the problems with Chinese restaurants is that, when a new owner takes over, they'll change the Chinese name but keep the same English name. The Eight Immortals of my youth (Jiu Baht Seen) is now Eight Immortals (Lai Yun).  Rumor has it that these are the folks who ran the Empress Garden restaurant on 9th Avenue in the Inner Sunset (the one that has stood empty for ages).

What I've learned: Just because a Chinese restaurant is crowded with Chinese people doesn't necessarily mean the food served is good. It can also mean that the food is cheap. Peking Spareribs, Beef Skewers on a hot plate, Eight Ingredients clay pot, and steamed rice for two was $21.70 (incl. tax). Portions are huge, but you don't really want to take it home afterwards.
author: Eating Sleeping T.

description:
My family loves this place.  We have been going here for years.  Even my fussy Hispanic friend who doesn't like anything other than Mexican food and burgers liked it.  Our favorite is the fried won ton soup - not many places make hung tow won ton.  

Ya it gets crowded.  If you see a ton of Chinese people there, and there are a hundred other Chinese places to eat in the Sunset, you know it has to be good.  Prices are very reasonable, too.

I just went back here.  Wanted to check it out again because the old owner retired about 6 months ago, and now there is a new owner.

I'm glad to report the new owner was smart enough to keep the same cook, and the same help.  And the same prices.  We ordered 5 different dishes, and all were very yummy.  So yummy I came back the next day and ordered the same thing.  

Definitely still a fan.
author: Marty C.

description:
Coming back here after about 8 years made me remember why my brother (then a starving student) loved this place.  In fact, he still does. 

The food was no-frills, cheap and decent (or at least good enough for a starving student).  For the two of us, we had two dishes and (free) rice and tea for $18.

The service was non-existent, but enough to justify the $8-a-dish price tag.  They wouldn't bother asking how the food was and you'll have to ask to top up your tea, but they're not rude by any stretch of imagination, and that is good enough for me.
author: Ange L.

description: Just went here for dinner with my family.  The food, service & decor was awful.  Not the same management.  Went here when I was a kid almost 20+ years ago with my grandpa -- loved the food, service & decor back then.  The original owners were Asian-Peruvian -- it was very interesting seeing Asian people speak Spanish!!!  Fluently - LOL Anyway, this place used to have a line out the door.  Now the tables are empty -- not sure how this place stays in business.  Go try it for yourself...don't say I didn't warn you...BEWARE!!!
author: Kristina T.

description: Used to come here for fresh ingredients and cheap prices but after today, I don't want to come back.  Even traditional dishes lacked flavor.  Service sucks on top of that.  Plenty of cheap eats in the area, go somewhere else!
author: Tessa M.

description:
3.5 stars seems about right for this place. Pretty good, but not spectacular. Don't understand the fetish with sliced white onions in most of the dishes, but the seafood is great.

Any of the squid, clam or oyster dishes I've tried in the past here are very good. Definitely try the Beef cubes with black pepper as well. First rate. Soups are ok.

Again - not gourmet, but pretty solid.

Ser vice is pretty good. Waitresses are always friendly.
author: Owen R.

description:
My extra spicy Mongolian beef was really bland, had to eat the spicy dry red peppers to get some flavor in there, but the meat was good (not spoiled), the vegetables were not wilted, and the price is awesomely cheap ($5.50 for my beef .... you can walk in here with a $5 bill, 20 quarters, or a $2 bill and 3 ones and leave with more food than an average person can eat in one sitting.  Prices here make Quiznos seem expensive)

It's a literal stone's throw (depending on wind) from my new crib so I will be back to eat very often, though if it were more than 10 blocks I would probably look for a closer incredibly bland tasting yet very edible Chinese food spot.

PS, do not go here at 11:55 on Mondays (and maybe every day, remains to be seen).  I walked in at 11:54, ordered with no problem, then one minute later 30-40 high school kids rushed in and filled the place up.  It was probably the very lucky difference between me getting my food in 10 minutes vs getting my food in one hour had I not walked to 8 Immortals at such a brisk pace.
author: Greg J.

description:
Service: 3/5
Food: 3/5
Wait: 2/5
Price: $
Presentation of food: 3/5
Presentation of restaurant: 3.5/5
Overall: 3/5

They have great Lunch Deals! So i suggest going during lunch time. Usually comes with a Free Drink with your meal.
author: Eva H.

description:
First of all we all know if you get food to go it usually taste like shit when you get home. haha Just had to put that out. My friends and I go to 8 Immortals quite a bit and the thing that brings us back all the time is the house spare ribs, yummy crunchy tender beef smothered in a sweet sauce. 

I'm not a fan of sauces over your food because I believe restaurants try to MASK the taste of the ingredients but this item was spectacular!!!
author: Harry K.

description: This is the best Chinese food. Enjoying the food with family and cousins with party of 9.  This place is so small and fancy. The people are nice and friendly.
author: Samuel C.

description:
Amazing food, great atmosphere and full of asian people, you know what they say, when a chinese restaurant full of asian people, the food is definitely good. Try anything on their menu that says 'salt and pepper', they are all equally amazing. Servers are not so great but it's compensated by the food.

The price is extremely reasonable, a little less on the portion though but not so little that you'd be hungry when you leave. 

The bad thing, I moved away to St. Louis so I can't really go regularly to this place anymore. But you can bet that whenever I visit my family again in SF, I'd definitely go this restaurant again and eat there. Ok, now I'm hungry.
author: David M.

description:
3.70 stars.

Came here a bunch of times mostly with my family. The food here is good and fairly authentic. But you NEED to try their hot sauce that is on the table in the little jar. I think they made it themselves. It's a nice spicy flavor. Toss some on your rice or noodles and enjoy with a cup of tea or water!

The place is small (although they have a second level), so it does get crowded and warm inside (especially if you're eating the hot sauce!).

I would recommend this place.
author: Sam W.

description: This is my absolute favorite Chinese restaurant in SF. My favorite dish is the salt and pepper eggplant dish....thinly sliced eggplant tempera but with a lighter batter. I also like their rock cod with tofu dish. This place is my favorite go to place for yummy Chinese food on the weekend. I highly recommend it. The waitress always remembers me since I order the same dish. They are very friendly here.
author: Kim K.

description: Most fresh Chinese food I've had good seafood. And great prices
author: Roxanne O.

description:
OH MAN this restaurant added to my love for Taraval street!

Despite not being high class, it has a very homey feel, and you KNOW you're getting homemade dishes, not typical, franchisey, dishes. I recommend 2 dishes. I know that's in cantonese but write it down, say it, and the waiter will understand you. If not, call me, and I'll talk to the waiter. : ):

"ying yeung chow fan": This is called ying yeung because it's "ying yang." Basically, the dish comes out as fried rice, divided in half by the sauce it is coated with. One half is caoted with a sticky sweet and sour sauce containing onions, and pineapple, I believe (there might be more, it's been awhile). The other half is coated with a thick sauce as well (contains starch of course to get that texture), containing egg whites, peas, carrots, and shrimp. EXCELLENT BABY.

"ham yu guy lap chow fan": This is your typical fried rice, minus, the shrimp, the chinese sausage, but instead containing salty anchovies bits, and chicken. IF you can't stand saltyness or seafoodyness, please don't order this dish. It is a famous dish and I think the chef makes it just right! It's only salty in the sense that the bits of fish are salty. It is evenly dispersed though.

The fried rice of 8 immortals are great, it's not too dry and not too wet. When you chew, it has enough air and rice dispersed that within your mouth, you feel the individual grains. Cool huh? Give it a try.

ho ho siq! - yummy in cantonese!
author: Brian C.

description:
DON'T WASTE YOUR TIME OR MONEY ON THIS PLACE.

I never go to a chinese restaurant for the service because most chinese restaurants don't understand what service is. I go for the food.

The food was just okay and the service sucks.

I'm not going to waste any more time telling you the details, you've been warned.
author: William W.

description: The food is cheap but it is not that good. 40 something for a group of five isn't too bad but we didn't like the complementary soup nor the dessert. The service sucks too. It wasn't even that busy.
author: Sarah C.

description:
I had high expectations riding into this place based upon my sister's rec.  Sadly, the food just did not match my expectations.  In fact, it was pretty underwhelming.

On the menu this night was wintermelon soup (eh), clams in black bean sauce (eh), beef steak with gailan (pretty good), beef brisket clay pot (nothing special), and lobster with ginger and green onion (good, not great).

James T. thought they were just off tonight and thought we should give them a second chance another time.  May be.  Solid may solid be.
author: Bob C.

description:
I wouldn't say that this place serves the best chinese food, or that it serves good chinese food, but some dishes are really worth coming back:

the best must-order dish every time i visit is the Deep Fried Squab! It is tender, juicy, fragrant, etc! It tastes exactly like those famous fried squabs in Hong Kong, except that this is in SF! Its not in the menu, but just mention it to them and they will definitely make it for you.

The salted pork ribs and the other dishes are also not bad...but not worth coming back for...
author: Crystalella S.

description:
Is the food here supposed to make you feel immortal? Because I felt like dying. It wasn't the worst Chinese food I've had (close!) but my tastebuds definitely did not enjoy getting raped. 

Chinese food is already cheap. If you come here to save yourself 50 cents on Kung Pao Chicken, you're doing yourself a disservice. At least I got the food to-go so I wouldn't have to put on a happy face and fake that I liked the food. You should have seen some of the faces I made at home though. I could have done another 48 faces if it wasn't for the Botox.
author: Jen Y.

description: This place recently just changed owners. The previous owners kept this place in good shape and was sad that they are gone. As a result, the happy hour is no longer available and the cook and menu seems to have changed as the food does not taste as good as before. It feels they americanized the food a bit. I am now looking for a new place in the sunset for my chinese food fix as my two usual places have gone down in quality and customer service. I wouldn't really recommend this place to anyone as there are better chinese restaurants.
author: Robert Y.

description:
This place is crackin lackin :)  The prices are very decent.  The service was off the hook, the place looks small, but dont be fooled, there is an upstair that caters to large parties.  

So my family and I order approximately 10 dishes:
-fried shrimp tofu (so delicious, soft on the inside, crunchy on the out)
-seafood soup (tasty, no need for soy sauce)
-salt n pepper shrimp
-salt n pepper crab
-black bean clams
-black bean oyster
-ginger chicken (wasnt really that good, not much meat and its cold)
-crunchy seafood noodle
-some fish my dad ordered
-walnut prawns

all that for one low price of $98. This is a two thumbs up place to eat.  I like it and i will go back :)
author: Mimi S.

description:
I have been coming to this place since...FOREVER practically.  
Every time that I do come here, our family orders the same thing EVERY time. It's kind of like a tradition. So, let me just tell you... this place isn't one of those "squeaky clean" Chinese restaurants. I also recommend to never use the bathroom here... trust me. hahahahaha. At least the food is quite decent though! One thing you really have to try is their honey walnut prawns. ITS OH SO GOOD.
author: Susie N.

description:
Beware! I think this is a front for the chinese mafia or something, at least thats what I think, how else could they justify such cheap prices for fresh seafood here, something is not right, I'm afraid. but I always look the other way (at my neighoring tables of course to get the inspiration for my order). But I'm too chicken to try out some their exotic items. (I will get the eventually, need another few years in bay area).

I go here for dem clay pots, or 5 spice fried chicken, or whole fried grouper, or garlic sauteed spinach, etc etc keeps me happy.

modest wait, be it weekdays or weekend. place is good, real good.
author: An u.

description:
Its been a while since I last wrote a review - and unfortunately my experience tonite at 8 Immortals brings me back to Yelp with a vengeance. 

Forget just about everything you've read good about this place - it no longer holds true. The reputation that this establishment earned  is no longer valid as they have clearly changed their philosophy.  We ordered the $55 set dinner and added an additional dish for a total of 6 adults - and we left hungry.  The additional dish of Honey Walnut Prawns was acceptable - but there were literally a dozen shrimp.  Which wouldn't be bad if it were larger than a silver dollar.  Literally, these shrimps were sized 26-30.  (Shrimp is catergorized by size - so 16-20 would mean in one pound of shrimp - you'd fine 16-20 shrimp)  
Yes folks, we were charge $12+ dollars for less than a 1/2 lbs of shrimp and a bunch of candied walnuts. 

Sadly, the shrimp set the tone for the rest of the meal.  The lobster was easily under a pound.  The lobsters were the same size as the ones they serve at the Moonstar and Hokkaido buffets for an extra $2 bucks.  The ones filled with cheese.

The salt and pepper shrimp were the same size as the honey walnut ones - so I guess if you put both orders together, we'd get a pound of shrimp total. 

The quail was on the cheap side as well, a mere single whole quail cut in 1/6s.  The golden fried chicken was 1/2 a chicken and the fried flounder was also on the smallish size. 

The steamed oysters with black bean sauce was ok - but someone ate 3 of the 8 and wound up having really bad stomach cramps. 

The best dish was the gai choy with garlic was spectacular - it's probably the final connection to the previous greatness this restaurant once had.  I don't believe that I will ever choose to come back, which is unfortunate considering the service was adequate, and the decor reminded me of my younger years.   

No need to fight the lines to try to eat here.  You'll get a much better bang at any of the other Chinese restaurants on either Taraval or Irving.
author: Dennis Y.

description:
No one likes a chinese guy that doesn't speak chinese. No one. White people don't even like chinese guys that don't speak chinese guys. 

I've gone to this place periodically for years. It had been a long while since my last visit,  for the sake of making an appearance, i had to make a return trip. 

They have this new happy hour menu with dirt cheap Chinese food from 2-5PM. 8 immortals also added Hong-Kong style baked dishes to their menu (baked pork chop, chicken) for just $5!!! Most places its $2-$3 buckaroos more. Sadly it was pretty awful - one of the dishes had baked ham sandwich meat in it. Trust me, there is nothing Chinese about sandwich meat.

Anyway, the kicker: I had asked for bowls for the table - the guy brought 3 for our table of 8. Alright, that's my bad, i should have been more specific. My friends egged me on for not asking in Chinese. However, knowing my Chinese sounds very much like that of the caucausian persuasion, I did not dare. Once again, I asked the man for 5 more bowls. Unsuccessfully, he returned with 5 forks. And oh yes, I did once more dare to ask for bowls. And as almost expected, the man returned with the dirtiest ass bowl I've ever seen. It was diseased, had some type of leprosy on it. There was NO possible way, that bowl could have been washed, unless they choose to wash their dishes inside of a used toilet bowl.

Will I come again? You bet your bottom dollar.
author: Garrett W.

description: How can you go wrong when you have a menu with dishes that are between $3-$4 a pop? This was one of our favorite haunts when we lived closer to San Francisco. We'd get there early -- around 5pm as the crowds can be stifling especially on Fridays, Saturdays and Sundays -- and feast on 4-5 dishes for less than $30 for 4 people. You can even get a steamed fish for about $7 -- what a bargain. Their fried tofu is fantastic and string beans for about $3.50? A bargain or what? I had a 'party' here (2 tables of 12) and paid about $120 total (banquet menu mind you of about 12 dishes). Of course they were in a hurry to kick us out as soon as they finished serving up our last banquet dish as they had customers waiting for the tables, but hey, great food and pay next to nothing? We can handle the not-so-great service!
author: Anita L.

description:
Just went here recently to celebrate Chinese New Year with my family.
We have been coming here for the last 20 years.  Great Chinese dishes at a very reasonable price.

If you want to experience truly authentic chinese food, you must try 8 Immortals.  Check out the fried pig intestines, salt/pepper squid, beef stew clay pot, roast pork with oysters clay pot, pork with salted fish fried rice, steamed salted pork and other chinese soul food dishes.

This place is not PF Changs.  It is the real deal.....
author: Raider J.

description:
We've ordered take-out from here many times and never been disappointed.  We love trying items we've never had before and always liked them.
It's hard to make specific menu recommendations because we usually ignore the menu and just tell them what kind of dish we want.  It helps if you have someone who speaks Mandarin.
author: Philip C.

description:
They offer a brilliant happy hour between 3 to 5 PM with $1 Chinese drinks and $2 snacks.  Two dollars gets you pork and preserved egg porridge - a good size bowl of it.  They make the best version of this type of congee that I have had on the street.  The consistency was the best (cooked for a long time, broken down, thick but not too thick) and the flavor.  It had the strongest ginger flavor.  Plenty of preserved egg.  Good pork.  Fresh scallions on top.  The HK milk tea was decent.

I'm curious about their Hong Kong style dishes like baked spaghetti.

I've also been here for dinner several times.  Some of the dishes are very good (e.g., steamed tofu with shrimp) and others are just okay, so overall it's a good place with some inconsistencies and it's cheap.  Lots of seafood, a very long menu.  It can get crowded, so I wouldn't come during peak hours, or make a reservation if you need to come during peak hours.  They have several large tables so it's good for groups, large and small.
author: Lolia S.

description:
Coming to the Taraval block, I'm getting a bit nostalgic of the college days :tear:

You learn something new every day -- this place has an upstairs and I never knew it! Good to know for larger parties since this place is tiny. 

Good food and even better price. 

There were 9 in my party and we got the Mandarin Dinner menu for $8.50/person... they really gave us enough food to serve 12 and our bill was less than an Benjamin. The portions were great, the service was quick and prompt, but on this visit (close to closing time) the tea was tepid and there wasn't any ice for our water. And this is one Chinese place that didn't give a fortune cookie. hmm... 

Anyway, haven't been disappointed eating here yet.
author: Alyson C.

description:
So I came here with a few friends for dinner on a friday night. My parents had gone there back in the day and said it was great then. They key word in that sentence is THEN. It wasn't terrible but it was 'great' to say the least. It was cheap and affordable and clean. After we ordered and got our meals they were steaming hot. But it seemed as if, after 5 min, that they were really cold. What is up with that?? 
The waiter was nice and helpful. And the register lady seemed really familiar i swear i think she works at another chinese resturant we had visited... down the street? Idk maybe i was hallucinating. Anyways overall it was an oookay experience. Maybe it was just a flook and i was being picky but haven't plucked up the courage to go and try again yet. Most people who have reviewed rave about the cheap prices. I would like it a lot better if the cheap prices pretty much summed up the taste of the food too.
author: Kimberly Y.

description: We dig this place first for the prices. Prices are like dated back to the early 90's! We also love the food: recently tried the Lobster noodles (perfectly seasoned), the crab with green onion could have been seasoned more, but the honey walnut prawns, chicken dishes, minced beef soup, and conch were tasty.  The food's not too greasy either.  They're generally very attentive.
author: Quan T.

description:
I loved this place in high school. Cheap ass food for a pretty large portion. The place is small though. The tables are super tiny. The chairs are super tiny. I do not fit. I'm kicking my friends sitting across from me. There is no arm length at all, but that brings the table closer, no? The bathroom's also pretty clean.

When I came here in high school, they gave me much more food at a much lower price. What happened?!

I came here recently with friends, and the portions were puny. It didn't even come close to filling me up. The food is still pretty much average Asian food - it hasn't really changed. I'm not exactly complaining, but why are the portions so small? Oh wait, it's just a few bucks. That's fine. I will just think of it as a snack.

The food here is cheap, and it's pretty decent, although the quality has lowered. Other than that, try it out, I think it's a hit or miss for most folks.
author: Glen H.

description:
This was once a five star restaurant for me but the owner began to skimp on the amount of food he used to offer.  That said, there's no better place you can go for excellent chinese food at rock bottom prices.
