Asians in the know always order two or more of the following: salt and pepper crab, clams with black bean sauce, fried flounder, roasted or braised squab, combination seafood with bean curd in clay pot, ginger and onion lobster, peking style spareribs, steamed oysters with black bean sauce, honey walnut shrimp (big fatty shrimp, not that puny crap), and steak and ginger and onion on iron plate.

One additional note: their homemade chili sauce is amazing.  But if you order take out, they will give you a tiny a** cup of it.  Do what everyone else does - open your food right then and there and just add some heaping spoons of the chilli sauce right into the food.
author: Angela K.

description:
Used to be an avid fan of 8 Immortals, as you can get pretty good food for a good price here, but like Gregory H mentioned, something's different.  Maybe change of cooks...

Their hot chili sauce is good, especially with the food if you like a little kick but BE FOREWARNED...if you dine in and have left overs, the older gentleman at the counter (the owner, I'm assuming) WILL NOT give you hot chili sauce for your left overs.  AND if you order to go, you get ONE small container.  I mean geez, come on!  

A friend of mine even offered to pay $$ for more, but he refused.  Don't know if he's trying to keep you coming back for more or if he's trying to protect his recipe.  Whatever the reason...it's got me puzzled...thought restauranteurs wanted to keep their customers happy!?!?
author: Row M.

description:
I've grown up going to Chinese restaurants with bad service (not to say 8 immortals has bad service but it ain't that hot) so it doesn't really bother me...or maybe I'm just racist =P

Anyways, if you know what to order, the food is freaking awesome.  If you don't, you might end up with mediocre/good food.  My aunts and uncles frequent this place so they always know the best dishes to order.  I'll say their wintermelon soup is always a favorite of mine.  If you're having a large party, I'd suggest calling ahead and asking for the wintermelon soup served in the wintermelon.  Not sure what they do but it tastes better.  Their squab is usually pretty good too.  I really liked their fatty pork in mustard greens.  They always do their clams well.  And when ong choi is in season...OMG, it's over.  You can have it cooked with garlic or shrimp paste...dun matter, it's delicious.
author: Eddie L.

description:
Eight Immortals.. hmmm.. definitely a strange name for a restaurant, but nonetheless this place can boast  friendly service, delicious food, and very reasonable prices! 

The only drawback would be that I have no reason to come all the way out here unless I'm visiting friends in Sunset, or I'm going to the beach. 

Overall, I was surprised by the quality of food for the price. *Two Thumbs Up*
author: CHERiE Y.

description:
This is one of the restaurants that I used to regularly visited since my move to the States more than 20 years ago. They used to be very good (both price wise & food quality wise), and even though it's run down we keep going back cos we love it.  A year or two ago, they switched owner. I have been there twice since. Waiters there are very helpful and friendly. But food is not like before. Still acceptable given the price, but not a place I would visit if not because of my curiosity that pops once a while wanting to know how that restaurant is like now, and always a hope that perhaps it will be just like before. 

BEWARE IF YOU ARE ORDERING SEAFOOD CHARGED BY WEIGH

One thing I really dislike about this place (and the reason for the 2 star instead of 3) is their dishonest business practice. And we may just never return again just because of this.  We had ordered steamed fish in both visit, and each time they would way over quote the weigh of the seafood (fish & lobster pricing is by weight). Their $ per pound pricing is lower than some restaurants, but they decide to cheat on the weigh instead to make even. The fish we got is max 1.25 pounds. We were quoted 1.7 lbs. Even worse in my last visit. We got something 1 pound max, and got quoted 1.7 lbs. Same with lobster. First time when that happened, I decided to let it go (thought perhaps it was a mistake?). Today I decide to talk to the owner, and as expected got some lame excuse (she tried to blame it on the waiters & insist the fish is right size...come on...she should know better than me) Frankly I want them to earn $, but I think customers would feel better if you charge a market $/pound rate and be honest about the actual weight.  I know it is not unusual for restaurants to quote ~a bit~ higher weigh (and I accept the fact), but please don't over do it thinking your customers are dumb.
author: BonBon H.

description:
I have trouble deciding whether to give it a 2-star or 3-star. Their horrible customer service really turns me off, but on the other hand, their fair pricing with decent quality of food tells me to give them a 3-star review. So I'm going with the latter. 
I like they're oyster with black bean sauce and peking pork ribs. 
Most of their dishes are around 7 bucks or under.
I usually do take outs and sometimes it takes forever for them to make food. So plan ahead before you call!
author: Mike S.

description:
We've recently moved to the sunset and decided that we want Chinese. So as we were on the hunt for a Chinese place we came upon this sign that says eight immortals and since my brother in law is highly into fantasy games this sign attracted us to it. Surprisingly this place is very very good.
The calamari is so soft and tender and fresh and the amount of batter and spices are just perfect. I love their moo shoo as well and the duck was very delicious also you have to try the clams in black bean sauce one more thing fish fillet with tender greens yummmmmmm. i highly recommed this place we ate more and this bill only came up to $60 we were stuffed and satisfied.
author: zoey x.

description: I used to come here a lot when I was younger (3-4 years ago) and was here recently for a family dinner. The owners have changed and probably the chef as well. However, the portions are good and the food is still tasty. I'll be nit-picky and say that the walnut shrimp used to be better but apart from that the other dishes were fine.
author: C K.

description: Went back the other day and need to write this update to confirm that the restaurant is under new ownership. The previous owner sold the business and has now retired. For the most part, food is still good...although one of their most ordered dishes, the deep fried flounder, was a bit rubbery and lacked the flavor it once had. I also noticed that they have a new snack-type menu to choose from (a la Quickly?)---unfortunately, I didn't get to try anything from this new menu.
author: Rod L.

description:
Everyone I knew back in high school told me it was the best place to eat during lunch time and it's cheap!

I guess it was... back in high school.  I went there recently with a large group and we sat at the two big tables.  We know our Chinese restaurants so we ordered accordingly, knowing what would feed our large group of hungry guys.

I wouldn't say the food is bad; that's why there are three stars next my review.  But the portions were not even comparable to other Chinese places.  We kept on adding orders.  By the time we were done, we realized we added 3-4 dishes on both tables!

It might be worth it if you want to see some nice long eyebrows on the cool waiter there.
author: Chris C.

description:
So sad, i wish i could give them higher.  This is going to be a long complaint.

So today, an old man convinced my mom that this place is REALLY good and has authentic Hong Kong style food.  So we came here to eat before dinner.  I have been here before with some friends and dont remember it being all that great.

Score free parking! Busted meter outside. (you'll be needing it)

Came in, empty.  Seated with menus...after looking at it, i dont see anything thats "authentic hk food" I saw, Roti with curry, Mexican fried rice (wth is that??) indian fried rice, cesar salad, and finally something i saw that i wanted, Hoi Nam Gai Fan - Chicken over chicken fat fried rice! my fave!

OK, ready to order, waiting, waiting, after about 15mins of waiting, i finally decided to throw my hands in the air and wave em' like i just dont care for some service!  I usually dont do that, because they will eventually come.  Finally, the waitress/owner lady sees me, so i say to her "we're ready to order" still optimistic..then she says, "one minute." and walks off into the kitchen!  GAH!

Finally she comes back and takes our order....and tell me that the chicken rice play i wanted is not cooked with chicken fat........WHAT?!?!!? then its just regular chicken and rice..who wants that?!

So we ordered the roti, deep fried mini fish, won ton noodles, and a baked spaghetti with ox tongue.  I think that is a good amount of food to tell whether they are good or not.

The service is bad, can the food please at least be good? 
Waiting, waiting......then these regulars came in...and got a smile and prompt service from this waitress/owner.....UGH! AND they got free food that came out before our paid food came out..

How do you expect us newbies to become regulars when you have such a bad attitude?

Now sitting there waiting for our food, i told my mom, that old man that boasted about this place mustve been a regular with special treatment.

Wonton noodles came out first, luke warm.............................ROAR!
mini fish that came out.....covered in spices, but bland..how could this be??
Roti with curry sauce- roti was like that chinese green onion cake. and the curry sauce had a layer of hardened curry on top protecting the watery curry sauce. fail.
spaghetti....i dont want to continue on...

Best thing i had here was my lemon iced tea.
total came to about $19, not bad, but i still feel ripped off.

At least there was a show towards the end of this disaster.
This man seated at a table by himself started to yell about nobody serving him.  Then he said something about he has anger issues and some kind of mind disease (he said it in chinese) and might hit someone if he doesnt get some service soon. The waitress lady was arguing with him all whilst my mom putting some money down so we can gtfo.
author: kim w.

description:
You can't beat satay clams for $3.50.  This is a great restaurant with delicious food and cheap prices.  

The only thing negative is they don't take reservations unless its a large party and the wait can take a while.
author: Brandon L.

description:
There is no better deal for your dollar than spending it here.  If you want old school hearty Chinese food, go here.  The owners haven't changed their prices in several years at least since 1999!!  They still have several items for $3.50 on their menu.  

Recommendations:
-steam oysters on the half shell
-fried fish (loon lay)
-boiled shrimp with soy sauce dippings
-fried chicken w/shrimp chips
-veggies w/fish filets

Everything is good, you won't regret it for the price!  It would probably cost you more to buy the items and prepare on your own.  

Note: long waits during dinner hours, early birds advantage here. For dessert go, next door for Marco Polo ice cream!
author: Mel S.

description:
This place used to be CHEAP, I mean REALLY cheap!  That definitely has changed throughout the years - of course, given that everything has gone up in pricing.  I used to always come here as my FIL refuses to go elsewhere since this is very close to their home.  Seating can be limited during dinnertime and weekends but the owners (the old couple) would give us a seat right away, as my in-laws are old-timers at the place.

Overall, food is so so but I think majority of the family owned Chinese restaurants around the area are almost the same.  Not bad for a quick bite or a cheap family dinner.
author: Andrea Y.

description: I just found out they sell Shark Fin soup - and I think that's disgusting. This was a restaurant I would pass by all the time, since it was in my old neighborhood. Had no idea that it was a buyer of shark fins. I loathe the practice - they should stop.
author: Elizabeth Z.

description:
This place is okay. My family always comes here for quick chinese food. The prices are pretty cheap since it's like a family restaurant, so it's not too expensive. Recently they added a 2-5 pm afternoon tea special which you can order certain dishes for $2 and drinks for $1. Just what I like! Since I love cheap eats! who can go wrong with that? They have soup noodles, fried noodles, porridge, fried chicken, fried fish, french toast, and more. Their portions are decent too so it's not bad. Other than the afternoon tea menu, their other dishes are pretty good too. Like their fried noodles and veggies. 

The restaurant is ok. it's not that nice looking. I think I would just come here if I want some decent chinese food.
author: Jessica W.

description: With a name like Eight Immortals, one would assume that they served food that was worthy of the gods!!!!!! It wasn't - well it was cheap. The food was decent and everything tastes better with good company! I love friends. However the dessert sucked. Watered down red bean soup makes me want to move the mouse a little over to the left to deduct one star ...
author: Dorian T.

description:
My favorite Chinese restaurant in the neighborhood.  I've been eating here with my family since I can remember, which is 10+ years.  The guy who runs the place is very nice and he speaks to customers occasionally.  He even speaks Spanish as he once lived in Peru (I see him talking to Mexican guys even now and then).  
As for food, my family's not too adventurous, especially during lunch.  Having been here over 50 times in my life, it goes like this (in Cantonese): 
1) wide flat noodle with beef (gon chow gnau hau)
2) mongolian beef with rice
3) tofu w/ fish in clay plot (dao fu ban kau bo)
4) salt and pepper spareribs

I've been here so many times that I could tell when they changed chefs and waiters/waitresses.  But they do make everything suitable to my taste buds.  I've never had a single bad experience coming here.  The waiters, once in a while, even make Cantonese jokes.  They actually smile and speak fluent English.  A little side story: I guess the owner treats us special b/c let's say there's a large party that has booked a table at 7:00pm and we come in at 6:00pm, he'll let us sit at that table.  He knows that my family will finish by 6:45 (maybe even faster since we're fast eaters).  Overall, Eight Immortals (Lai Yun in Cantonese) is a great family restaurant.
author: Stephen H.

description:
DIRT Cheap and good.. a little greasy but ooo.. itz hard to resist their dishes, it taste just like homecook meals.. my personal fave: black bean clams, steamed fish, house special chicken (nt sure if it's that's what it's called on the menu)... whatever you order, I'm pretty sure it would taste good. 

Go early, coz the wait is long after 7pm..
author: Kym L.

description:
My ex and her family got me open to this place. This was one of their family places to eat for a treat. And now this is my favorite Chinese restaurant ever. Great tasting, authentic food and the prices I definitely cannot complain about. These two things are the two main factors which attract me to a restaurant and keep me coming back. It's been a minute since I've eaten here, but I'm reminded that I gotta return soon!

Update (March): after many moons, I finally went this weekend cuz my friend was visiting from out of town so I thought I'd share my favorite spot. He became an instant fiend and wanted to go back the next day. 3 people, 6 dishes = only $42. My favorites are walnut prawns, orange chicken, crispy taro duck. (burp!)
author: Epicurious M.

description:
Ever eaten such good food that you never really feel full?

That's what happened when I went to the Eight Immortals. It might have been the fact that I hadn't had Chinese food for a REALLY long time, but I thought the food was pretty darn good here.

Porridge, chicken, beef, dumplings.. everything was pretty great. The only complaint I had was that my very white boyfriend at the time wanted Orange Chicken, and since I'm not a fan, I didn't think it tasted very good; it was way too sweet. Hello cavities.

Otherwise, yum :)
author: Tori S.

description:
Cheap, good food. You simply cannot beat their lunch prices. $3.50 for a rice plate! VERY inexpensive.

Cons:
- Atmosphere is a bit stuffy.
- Portions for lunch are small. I sometimes order 2 lunch species, bringing the price to $7, but it's still significantly larger than any offering anywhere else. Portions for dinner are adequate.
author: Karl K.

description: I could not believe the wide selection at such low prices.  The portions were very generous and the low price (6 dollars for Mushu pork?) did not mean there was any issue with quality.  The staff is very friendly and likes to see you smile.
author: Hanuman R.

description:
My boyfriend's family use to go here anytime we had a visitor.  They give big portions and the food is really cheap.  The quality is good but not great.  We haven't been here in a while because we just got tired of the food and the crowd.  

We usually order the same thing each time...salt and pepper spare ribs, steam or deep fried fish, honey walnut prawns, clams in black bean sauce.... 

My friend tells me that the crispy hong kong style noodles are really good and cheap too. Each time she eats here with her family, they always order it to go for the next day.

The only downside is that they charge for each bowl of white rice.  It is probably more cost efficient to order fried rice instead.
author: Cin T.

description:
WTF happened man?
I used to eat here twice a week and loved it. Just came back and ate there again and WTF? Where is the freaking MSG granules that I love so much on your crispy pork chop, why is it now bland and soggy with oil? Crispy deep fried fish nicely done in soy sauce, emmmm  have you changed the oil recently? No flavor to your soup???? What happened. I anticipated wait line out the door but no line the day I came, is that a good thing or a bad thing? I missed you my old 8 Immortals.
author: John L.

description: Went back recently and noticed that the placed changed ownership.  No more Mr. Grumpy at the desk and food is still okay.  More likely to go back now that they are friendlier.
author: M Y.

description:
Very good chinese restaurant.  A bargain.
Love their steamed oysters on shells, and many of their dishes.
Will be back over and over again.  Check out their many pot dishes
and sea food dishes.
author: Denis Y.

description:
If you read the SF Chron's food review guidelines it says that they visit a place at least three times before writing a review.  You know.., to ensure objectivity and to make sure they try different types of food and stuff.  So if I follow that guideline, I should've been writing a review for Eight Immortals nine years ago.  

But I didn't.  So here's the long overdue review:
Downright good Chinese food.  Now it may be Chinese-American food, but alls I know is it's good stuff for a little bit of money.  Sounds Chinese?  Well count me in.  Things we always get: deep-friend flounder (don't forget to eat the crunchy side fins, they're like chips!), salt and pepper spare ribs (make sure it's the dry one, not the sweet and sour kind), any seasonal veggie they recommend sauteed in garlic (look around other tables for ideas).  The chili they put on the table is also insanely good.  I'm not sure if it came from a jar but I have yet to find it in Sunset Super or Pacific, so I'm thinking it may be made in-house.  

So if you're a bit broke but your in-laws are coming to town, do take them here for a Chinese food meal without the hassle of Chinatown.  By the way, street parking is very easy.  I should know because I used to live a block away...
author: Yohanna B.

description: I went here with some Chinese friends and I have been trying to figure out what they ordered ever since.  The spicy salt and pepper pork chops were top notch, salty and crispy and great.  Chinese broccoli and... beef maybe was sooo good.   Eggplant beef was good but more sweet than I wanted.  The staff speaks functional English but I am pleased to note that they treated me the same when I was with Chinese speakers as when with just English speakers.  Actually the service was fine, a little uneven sometimes lousy sometimes really conscientious and overall good.  The prices are freaking cheap.  Dont get the combo appetizer, it is small, the fried prawns and springrolls are unremarkable/boring.  The fried pork was delicious.  I am glad I live near.
author: Mitchell M.

description: This place stands out somewhat because of its red brick exterior. The dining room is relatively small, only about a dozen tables or so. That's why often, especially on weekends, there may be a bit of wait for a table. The menu choices are extensive and quote economical. I noticed many good choices for about $5. They even have a "single diner" set menu, but in that case I think it's better to order an entree or two with possibly a soup.
author: H K.

description:
There is much, much, much better Chinese food in San Francisco than this place. I was born and raised in Cupertino but went to school in Davis, so while I know what good Chinese food tastes like, I also have a healthy realization that not everything will taste like it should.

This restaurant, however, is TERRIBLE. I went here for a Chinese New Year eve dinner to pick up some items to go. I had to wait in the small, tight, unpleasant interior for an hour. I stood for most of that hour.

I was willing to give them some slack since it was a Chinese holiday, but I was told by a fellow diner that this place was always this packed. He was American, which should've given me some pause, but everyone else was Chinese. It must be worth the wait, I reassured myself.

It wasn't. The food was bland, uninspired crap. Even the taro duck which sounds interesting and unique was tasteless mush. The duck was mostly duck fat.

The chinese spare ribs hardly have any meat on them and aren't even spare rips, quite frankly. They're more like pork chop bones with tiny fragments of meat.

This restaurant caters to the Western palate, which is weird since there were so many Asians dining there. With all the small children at each table, however, I don't suppose the restaurant was facing the harshest critics. The parents probably just wanted the cheapest meal for a bunch of hungry mouths.

====

Rubric: 5 = Mindblowing 4 = Excellent 3 = I see the charm 2 = Disappointing 1 = Never again
author: Eric K.

description: I love coming here for lunch! It's only two blocks away from my school! And  the lunch prices are very decent! About 3 dollars for a meal? Also,  I know the owner as well. She's awesome! And really friendly too. During lunch, you need to call in before you enter the restaurant because it's always so busy because of the high schoolers. But overall it's great and I enjoy coming here for lunch and dinner as well. Every friend of mines come down here for lunch. Their food is delicious!
author: Sandy C.

description: This place rocks!  I ate dinner with my Dad the other night and we ordered clams in black bean sauce, a clay pot, and Peking spareribs.  The clams were fresh, the clay pot was piping hot, and the spareribs were simply delicious.  It was so good, we ate the whole table and barely crawled out on account of being so full.  Eight Immortals is a great substitute for those of you who cannot fly to Hong Kong every week ;-)
author: Angela D.

description:
I'd call this place a "kind of hole in the wall." With all the restaurants on Taraval Street, this one is easy to miss. I'm glad my friend brought me here.

The food is reasonably priced! It is fairly cheap, and yet it is really, really tasty. One of the best chinese foods I've ever eaten. Plus, their portions are pretty big.

The restaurant itself is somewhat small, and is kind of messy, but it is more than okay for the price you pay.

Try this restaurant for a nice chinese cuisine lunch, dinner, or anything!
author: Gabe R.

description: OMG . I LOVE this place . For cheap fast legit chinese takeout this seriously is as good as it gets . Half a star off khs of the ehhcustomer service... but honestly for less than 5 dollars for an entire GOOD meal, I don't mind waiting extra minutes & dealing with ehh attitudes . I always get minced beef with egg over rice . They put enough sauce over the rice to give it flavor but not too much as to smother it . Love Love Love .
author: Desiree C.

description: Very good Chinese food at reasonable prices. I have eaten at MANY more expensive restaurants that don't serve near the quality of this establishment. The help was very polite as well even though I think she had trouble distinguishing the "word that were coming out of my mouth".  The decor outside and inside is nothing to write home to mom about but I wasn't really concerned about that either.
author: Rod M.

description:
Reading the reviews, fellow Yelper Jeff W. saw that Hung Tao Yee wonton soup  was served and said, "We've got to eat there!"  So off we went.  

Surprisingly we didn't have to wait for a table.  However, said table was so greasy, that I would have gladly waited to waited to if it was being cleaned.  I did ask the server to wipe the table.  She reluctantly did so.  The whole restaurant has a grungy feel to it.  

By the way, the name refers to the eight immortal characters in Chinese mythology.  While many are patrons of different professions, cooks aren't included. 

We ordered the Hung Tao Yee wonton soup which was delicious.  Deep fried wontons in an egg drop broth with cilantro.  Yum!  We also ordered salt and pepper prawns which were tasty.  As a side, we asked if they had dow miao (pea tips) which were served with garlic.  The dow miao was also delicious, but I found myself picking out gray or other odd colored pieces of dow miao which makes me believe the kitchen doesn't clean or at least inspect their product very much.  Considering how grimy the restaurant looks, I'm not surprised.

I'd go back just for the soup, but be wary of other dishes.  Look before you pop something into your mouth.
author: Scott S.

description:
The food was good! We had their "fish with parsley" soup which featured fresh fish, tofu, and cilantro. Also had their clams with black bean sauce (also fresh). Their string beans ("say gway dao") was decent but a little on the sweet side. (I think I grew too used to the Sam Woo's style... which i still prefer.)

The best thing? You can gelato next door at Marco Polo's... : )

THANKS Ivy P!
author: Sabrina L.

description:
Good and cheap Chinese food. My family always orders take out from here and we're barely disappointed. 

Be sure to order the beef egg drop soup and egg drop shrimp flat noodles.
author: Teresa Y.

description: Standard Chinese restaurant.  Good sprouts, steamed fish, ginger oyster, and stir fried lobster.  Cleanliness is somewhat questionable.  If you want affordable Chinese food, this would be a good option.  Usually, you will see a sea of Chinese folks pack like sardines in there.  So, the noise level is loud and it could be just a little too croweded.  Not kid friendly at all.  Parking can be a challenge.  Again, affordable especially for banquet stlye dinners.  Try it and you'll decide.
author: D C.

description:
The food was decent! But the chow mein could use some work! 

We went on a really busy night and our server was stressed but still managed to be nice! The only let down was that at one point it felt like we were having two separate meals because two of our plates got held up in the kitchen. We ended up sitting around waiting for them for about 15 minutes. 

I would recommend sitting upstairs if possible- it seems less hectic and crowded than downstairs.

But other than that- 10 plates later... we seriously chuckled when we got our $58 bill- SO CHEAP!
author: Valerie A.

description:
This is an old family favorite mostly because of the price and the amount of food you get. We usually order from the banquet menu and everybody gets a little of what they want. I am favorable to seafood and greens. I like the crab, walnut prawns, and the cold appetizer platter. The food here isn't as greasy as other Chinese restaurants. Don't expect anything fancy here, it's a very casual place. The tables can be a little sticky and the settings are on a paper placemat. 

We recently got take out from here and my mom asked for little oil and no MSG. We got the exact opposite. The rice and noodles were drenched in grease and oil. It was so gross. I could feel my arteries clog as I ate the food. Yuck.
author: Candace F.

description:
I really like this small chinese restaurant. My family has come here in the past, but due to the fact that I tend to avoid ordering when my parents are involved, I tend to passively look and nod. Of course the family bickering tends to downplay the food as well.

This all changed very recently though. After perhaps a good five years of avoiding this place, I recently made a visit two weeks ago. Me and and the woman got the cantonese lunch special, and had some excellent won-ton soup, coupled with some fried egg rolls, stir fry rice, some sweet and sour pork, topped off with some stir fry beef with greens. 

Fried rice is possibly the best I've had in recent memory. Very light yet tasty. Doesn't taste oily, or super fried like most stir fry rice I've had in the past. It's seasoned lightly, and seems really light. The other dishes were excellent as well. The won-ton soup was very tasty and good as well.

My advice is to avoid the usual dining times, such as early morning during the weekends, and early dinner times, such as 5 till 7pm on any other day. Avoid the crowds, and you'll be pleasantly surprised as I was. Cheap too.
author: Clinton L.

description: Best bang for your buck when it comes to Chinese food in the Sunset. Food is cheap, portions are good, and the dishes are tasty.
author: Jae Young S.

description:
The restaurant has made quite a lot of changes since the last time I went there.. a few years ago. They added quite a number of dishes including curry dishes and prata. For their tea items, the $2 items include wonton noodles, beef stew noodles, macroni soup, spiced salt chicken wings (4 pc) and drinks like cold / hot lemon tea ($1). Its really tea items cos you'll probably need to order a few. My spiced chicken wings came out freshly fried. Its a chicken version of the spiced salt pork ribs. The wonton is nice too. Go try!! you can't find better deals in San Francisco.

** They are closed on Wednesdays
author: Catherine T.

description: Decent Chinese food at very affordable prices.  A good selection of different dishes.
author: Henry S.

description:
I do have quite a high standard for Chinese restaurants and Eight Immortals is probably on the Top 3 of all Chinese restaurants I've ever been to (including my previous 20 years of life back in Asia). Only thing that prevented a 5-star is the smallish and always crowded place.

As others have written, main selling points of this place are: cheap, cheap and cheap. By cheap, I meant really cheap, I think they charge like $4 for a big bowl of hot and sour soup that is enough to share for 4. And their hot and sour soup is better than the one that costs arms and legs at "The Mandarin" Chinese restaurant by Ghirardelli Square. 

Downsides are: really crowded and in a typical Chinese joint, of course, "no service". Then again at $4-6/dish, do you really expect any service?

With that said, if non-Asians (or non-Chinese) want to really taste "Chinese Food", this is THE place to go. It's not that their food taste crap because it's so cheap, it's excellent. 

Some items I'd recommend are: sizzling beef on hotplate, crabs (any style) and definitely the walnut shrimp. Another plus point is that it's a couple door next to Marcopolo gelato place, a good place to drop by after the meal.
author: Ferian J.

description: Judging solely on the food they serve here, I'd say 8 Immortals is pretty good for a decent price. Service is also good, although I've had one experience where the plates were really greasy and unwashed, but it was just once. The owner's really friendly, but lately there's just been so many new Chinese restaurants around the city, so we rarely come anymore. Good for its price and very cozy place :)
author: Cindy S.

description: charles loves their deep fried flounder, and for $5 (on their specials menu) that's a bargain.  i like to supplement with the steamed bean curd (comes with the shrimp "mix" on top).  dinner for 2 comes out to $10.
author: Lucy W.

description:
Even though I'm Chinese, I rarely eat Chinese food unless it's a family dinner. I'm pretty picky about Chinese food, and frankly, sometimes I just don't like it that much. However, a reliable friend highly recommended this place, so off we went.

I was not disappointed! There were only 3 of us, so we couldn't order that many dishes, but everything was good. We had the pea sprouts, fried tofu, and fried catfish, and everything was delicious. I was most impressed with how whatever they used to batter their fried foods was light, fluffy, and not at all oily! The fried tofu was probably my favorite dish of the three, with the outside being perfectly crispy, but the tofu soft and silky. The food here is pleasantly and surprisingly not greasy for being a kind of a divey-looking Chinese restaurant. The bill ran us $42 for those 3 dishes, which sounds a little high, but it was a huge fish and we probably had more than half left at the end of our dinner.

Not the BEST Chinese food I've ever had, but definitely better than most.
author: danae c.

description: I got the walnut shrimp, clams in black bean sauce, kung pao chicken, beef chow fun with extra gravy, and salted pork ribs.  The food was OK.  The walnut shrimp was pretty good but I expected it to be since it's supposed to be more pricey.  The clams and pork ribs were decent.  However, the KUNG PAO CHICKEN might as well have been vegetarian!  There were maybe 5 pieces of chicken of regular sized chicken slices...then the rest (and when I say rest, I mean hardly any) were LITTLE ITTY BITS of chicken amongst all of the bamboo and water chestnut.  Would've given this place a 2, but the service was pretty fast and the people are nice.
author: Cathy L.

description: Can't beat the price and the flavor.. This is already an institution. No frills but really good Chinese food. Been a fan for years. I recommend that after you eat here, walk a few steps down the street and have some exotic ice cream. Love this place!
author: Jorydude r.

description: My family took me here when I was in the bay area last summer. It was good but not as good as a Chinese restaurant in SF should be. In my opinion some of the Chinese places in Las Vegas were better. This place  is not that cheap either.Especially when they sucker you into buying the " fresh fish of the day"...which costs $40!!!! It is a decent Chinese restaurant at best. Hole in the wall atmosphere with hard to find parking. four  to five stars if this p[lace was in Iowa.
author: EJay D.

description: Decent chinese restaurant. Crispy chicken and tofu with the prawns on top of it were pretty good. Service was bad. We ordered duck noodle and it never came. We cancelled the order. The lady said it's okay but gave an excuse that they still cooked it and it was a busy night and that it'll take time to cook it. I mean 1 hour to cook noodles? Those three excuses were repeated like 3x so yeah... Those were excuses auntie. Bad service, okay food. I Bet I can find a better chinese restaurant in San Francisco. Learn from my experience
author: Cliff T.

description: This is a sacred place for the Chinese people not ready to eat among the white people. We aren't being racist, just too cheap to get forks. You have to understand.
author: Jean W.

description: I want to give this place 5 stars but i need to eat there a few more times. This is my favorite kind of chinese place. Not the fanciest decor, not so big, real cantonese, a place that regular locals enjoy. I really really like their fried flounder in their special entree menu. Great sauce and very filling. All the selections are very reasonably priced and they give you plenty. Great daily lunch specials very cheap and the quality is good. The locals are lucky to have this place.
author: yelp j.

description:
before getting plastered at DL came here with Bella, Junie, Basi and euge to treat the bday boyee to some din-din.  the layout is split into two sides for many parties to yell at each other and eat off one another's plates cause well that is what chinese people do right?

we did just that and more.  miss Cameron House herself (Bella of course!) dropped it like its hawt and ordered in cantonese (i think?) as euge drooled all over his menu with this look on his face that made you think he just creamed his pants.

because we relied on Bella to order and pick i don't know the names (like i would remember anyhow!!??!) of the dishes but we went family style and enjoyed a massive order of two different fish (one was baked and the other fried), gailon (crunchy and juicy!), fried spareribs (YUM), chicken and duck that was in fried taro--that one dish is a must to order people!!!!

service was solid, kitchen FAST, atmosphere- blegh, eats- YUMM!, beer- TSING TAO only =( and my company was alright...just playing!!!  love you guys =)  tons of leftovers still that we boxed up to bring for our drinking pals.

highlight of the dinner was watching one of my friend's get all mortal kombat and masterfully removed a fish eyeball, swirled her hashi around to catch all the juice and delicately ate that drippy, gooey, slimy nastiness-- and they were HUGE!!  damn savage chinese!
author: omar b.

description:
Man talk about tasty chinese food. Food is very good and very cheap. Actually it's too cheap to be true.......LOL.

They have the best chili sauce of all chinese restaurant I've been to. When you're done eating, walk next door for an ice cream heaven called Marco Polo.
author: George K.

description: Really good and fresh Chinese food at a very reasonable price!! I like the wide variety of dishes that they offer and some more unique dishes which other restaurants don't serve. Order from their specials section for some of their specialties such as the taro duck. I always leave satisfied after each trip to their restaurant and looking forward to my next trip there!
author: Lisa M.

description:
i used to come here with family and friends when i wanted cheap cantonese style set dinners with steamed oysters, honey walnut prawns, crab, manila clams sauteed with fermented black beans and fresh live fish either steamed or fried. and it was cheap. all of the dishes listed above, with soup and steamed rice and dessert for something around $68.

i'm not sure if that's the case any more (doesn't sound like it from the other reviews), but it's comforting to know that there is still decent cantonese food in the outer sunset that is relatively cheap.
author: May T.

description: Since So's on Irving closed...Eight Immortals has become my new favorite go-to place. I've also discovered a new favorite dish there--the fried tilapia topped with a thick sauce marinated in jalapeos.
author: Sue L.

description:
If I could give this place NO STARS I would.  I'm so disappointed from my experience there.

BAD customer service.
BAD food.
BAD interior design. 
BAD price.

Here's the scoop:  Go in and they sit you down in these cramped up tables and chairs that would normally fit 2 ppl comfortably but we have a party of 3!  I heard the service was bad but really I came for the food but was the service really that bad? YES, the chinese waitress commands, 'SIT HERE' and even if we barely had room they could have cared less and rolled their eyes.  They insist that although the half the restaurant wasn't full at 4pm for dinnertime, the bigger more roomier tables were reserved.  We ended up having all our plates and bowls side by side and eating elbow to elbow with some dinner plates utensils falling to the ground.  I'm not exaggerating their tables are really dinky and the place looks like a hole in the wall.  I don't think its that clean either.

So to the food, we ordered a grilled scallop dish and get this. They brought out a dish full of onions and had 3 broken up pieces of scallop which they charged about $8 for. The waitress decides not to send back the food, although thats what our request was. Its high way robbery to call that scallop dish, should've called it onion dish. We had to make a scene where other tables and the boss came out to see what the complaint was before they sent the food back to the kitchen.

Prawn and walnuts dish was decent but the price was outrageous $10 for only 6 pieces of small shrimps. What a rip.

Cabbage stuffed minced meat that greasy oil and bland flavoring. Price was $7 but so not worth a penny.

And last dish was a beef claypot that had greasy oil.

I'm a big fan of taking leftovers home, but this time I decided not to because those leftovers were not even decent for homeless people.
author: Peachie Y.

description:
My friends were offended when she was charged again for taking the leftover rice home.  The appetizer beef tongue was dry and tasteless.
The salt/pepper fried fish were also bland.  At least our winter melon soup was delicious (however, there weren't any 8 ingredients that is the norm for the soup).  On our menu we also dined on deep fried tofu with fried shrimp on top, garlic spinach (do-meu) and soya chicken which were fresh, tender and well-seasoned.  And last, the salty fish chicken fried rice did not have enough salty fish to taste.  With so many Cantonese Chinese restaurants in the area, this establishment wouldn't be on my preferred list.
*****************************UPDATE**********************
During the school season at lunch time (around Noon), Do Not go from Monday through Friday.  The restaurant has made that time for the students at Lincoln High School to buy their "rice plate" lunches for $3.25 (for us it's $4.25 per person). When my friends and I came at 11;30 am.  We made the mistake of sitting near the "banquet tables" and the students were served first and we had to wait for our orders (even though we ordered before their arrival).  We counted 40 students!
author: Marian G.

description: Eight Immortals seems very popular with the local asian community ... and being the round-eye that I am I've only tried a few simple dishes that I found to be just OK. I will warn you that the salt & pepper shrimp are whole shrimps ... complete with heads, shells, & legs. It was also fried & served with jalapeno slices. It wasn't for me and I couldn't eat it for what it's worth.
author: Todd F.

description: This place makes the best Chinese food you can find anywhere in the City and why?, because its a Peruvian-Chinese restaurant. Order Inca Cola.
author: Tony A.

description: large yummy platter of garlic spinach...cooked just right....pork, cod and bean cake claypot...simmering good....salted fried pork chops....bit over battered...but stick to your ribs good....steamed black bean oysters..warning...huge oysters...very very meaty huge oysters...ah..the fried flounder with sauce seemed magnificant...gotta try that next time.....cheap cheap cheap...$30 for 4 dishes....
author: Hen A.

description:
Portion size: small. Many dim sum places have more than their dishes.

Taste: Bland. Some are better than the others, but overall, I added a lot of soy source and spicy source.

Price: Seems cheap, but with some "hidden costs". Rice for example, is charged extra.
author: andy s.

description: Mmmm....  This review may be biased because I am on a food (maybe MSG) high...  I just had the Hung Tao Yee Wonton after craving it all day.  Thanks to Yelp I now have a go-to place for it.  I used to order it at a restaurant down the block from me, but since they're gone, I've been on a drought.  Now that I know where to go when I get a craving for it again!  They gave LOTS of wonton, I'd say close to 10-12, in my to-go container.  Unfortunately all of the green onion and cha-siu was stuck on the bottom of the container, so had I not dumped it out into a large bowl, I wouldn't have found it until the very end.  Delicious & I'm definitely coming back!
author: Allan H.

description: My go-to place for cheap, yummy Chinese food. Yes, it's not so clean and over-crowded and parking isn't easy either, but food is real good.  Sometimes that's all you need. Tip: yummy seafood!
author: Janina V.

description: great Chinese family eating joint. definitely helps if you speak Cantonese here. lunch or dinner works wells. one lunch dish that is offered here and NOT at every Chinese restaurant is the Hung Tao Yee Wonton. this dish consists of deep fried wontons in a thick egg drop soup with minced cilantro. my dad used to take the family to Chinatown every weekend to have this dish. I am thankful that this place still serves this type of Cantonese comfort food. 8 immortals is still a winner after all these years.
author: Jeff W.

description: Quality chinese food at reasonable prices. They cook every dish to specifications, and don't miss a beat. I highly suggest eight immortals!
author: Darius T.

description: My bf took me here on one of HIS chinese food cravings. Good and cheap. Order the chinese broccoli. And be nice to grandpa at the cashier's desk.
author: Mar M.

description: This place is yummy, fast and never messes up my order - BUT I wish they delivered!!
author: Donna L.

description: Seriously.......ICK.....Maybe it's because I might be into "white girl style" chinese food....or maybe its because I miss the hell out of Ha's or maybe jus maybe it;s because the food was just not good.  My co-workers and I had lunch from there today and I swear i think laying down in a hole somewhere might do me better than the way I was left feeling.  The food was way too greasy.....the flavor lacked....well alot and I now feel like someone is turning my insides into a tightly woven pretzel....short and sweet ONCE BUT NEVER AGAIN
author: Shaunna K.

description: I can always count on 8 Immortals for my salt and pepper squid, seasonal ong choy with garlic sauce, and salt and pepper pork spare ribs.  My family and I had several birthday banquets here, and whatever other occassion we can make an excuse for.  Impervious to the history behind this place, I honestly feel like this is a solid chinese diner that delivers consistently good quality food.  Be forwarned that there is limited seating (especially for parties of two) if you come during the busy hours which are 5-8PM.  And they barely have room for those who are waiting to be seated, so therefore have fun braving the chilly Sunset District wind when you wait outside.
author: Sam R.

description:
Yum Yum Yum. 
Most Chinese food in the city has somewhat Americanized, but this place, food still tastes like how mom used to make it. Price is cheap, waiter is rude, plastic never works, and they calculate every bill with an abacus. If you look Asian and speak any Chinese, speak it, it's expected. You don't get any more Chinese than this.
author: Gharliz g.

description:
okay. so it's ANOTHER 5 star review...

anyway. this one's a little biased, because i LOVE 8 immortals. okay. so they have bad service -- a LOT of chinese restaurants that are as busy as 8 Immortals have bad service, so cut them some slack. they're trying the best they can.

the chicken here is reallly good & i think they have THE BEST jellyfish (that's what it's called, right?) in the city. the soups are excellent too. and the place is pretty clean, compared to all those dirty smelly places in chinatown. it gets 5 stars alone for being so cleannn!
author: Betty T.

description: Good food at CHEAP prices! whats not to like?
author: Will M.

description: Love this place. Because the food is cheap and good. the portion is just about decent for the price. Of course, if you go at the wrong time. [busy hours] you don't get much service at all. and the food takes a while to get to you. also the floor space isn't huge, so you have to wait a while for a table. also the table are on the smaller scale. so it can be a bit cramp. still i enjoy eating here. cozy and cramp up. XD
author: Karin L.

description: the food is arite, we order a dinner for 6 just wasn't cutting it... i was still hungry, the portion is some what smaller then i expected. but when you order the 2 combo to go its arite... under $5!
author: JessePanda C.

description: This is probably some of the tastiest authentic Chinese food you can get for cheap in the city. It's the special "hole in the wall" (not a very pretty place) that makes you keep coming back for more because the food is delicious and inexpensive - especially their seafood, YUM! The drawback is that there's always a long wait during prime hours and there is no where to stand when you're waiting to be seated. But for me, it's worth the wait.
author: Ivy P.

description: Cheap, tasty, no frills chinese! Most people that frequent here are chinese, and I think it's a hangout for lincoln students after school. Nothing so special about the setup, it's really all about the good food at great prices. Plenty of good meals here. I love the foo chow style fried rice as well as their fish selection. Yum!
author: Marv G.

description: Ownership has changed, and for the worse.  All the baked rice dishes off the HK-style Western menu are gone (supposedly for good according to the waitress), and I get the the hunch that the entire HK Western menu is probably go the same way soon as well (lots of "out of stock" items like French toast, cutlet dishes, etc.).  The waitress claimed the chefs didn't change, but I'm sure the old man that used to own the place took a lot of secrets with him into retirement -- Chinese-style beef fillet tastes different (less savory Worcestershire sauce flavor and more sour red vinegar flavor, beef has less "wok hei" stir-fried goodness), HK-style pan fried noodles are REALLY greasy now, mustard greens are lower quliaty and SUPER oily, and wet-stir fried beef chow fun tastes better than before (more "wok hei" stir-fried goodness and tastier sauce) -- hence the 2 star rating (I would've given this place 3 stars with the caveat of being careful what to order before the ownership change).
author: Ryan D.

description:
what can i say about this place?! its simply the best chinese food join id ever been in the city. its dirt cheap u cant complain. its fried chicked damn addicting u cant help but eat them whole to the bones!
they have happy hours too! service isnt the best, but hello! its chinese restaurants! u got me? parking isnt really a pain! definitely come back
author: Richard K.

description: A diamond in the rough...my boss recommended this place and I'm glad my husband and I tried it.  We ordered the sizzling rice w/ seafood soup, squid w/ salt and pepper, honey walnut shrimp, roast pork and oyster clay pot, and yan chow fried rice.  Everything was delicious!  The service did seem slower than other Chinese restaurants I've been to.  The food came one by one with the rice being last.  I'm assuming it was because they were very busy that night.  We'll still definitely come back.
author: Patricia B.

description: We were extremely happy with 3 dishes (jellyfish, black mushroom clay pot, water spinach with garlic) and just okay with one (seafood clay pot, it was quite listlessly a hodgepodge of no real distinct flavors). A little surprised that everything was slightly on the bland side since we specifically asked them to make the orders spicy. We requested and added some chili sauce and that kind of fixed the issue. This is definitely one of the better restaurants on Taraval and the low prices are really surprising (mostly $5-6 or maybe $8 per entree). Don't order too much, as the portions are HUGE. Lots of families eating here, and it is small and crowded, and the service is very rushed. It can be a struggle to stay calm and not panic and start shoveling massive amounts of food in your mouth, because it is kind of an overstimulating experience with all the servers rushing by you with huge sizzling plates over your head and 5 people within a few feet of you some of whom are touching you - I found myself really having to concentrate on eating slowly and not losing my sense of self, if that makes any sense. Take out might be an alternative if you're not feeling up to the crowd.
author: p v.

description:
I wished the portions were greater, but I guess quality is better than quantity in this case.

Easily one of my favorite chinese restaurants in the Sunset.
author: Jeff H.

description: I have been coming to this place for years... it's cheap and the portions are huge.  If you want to save some money order your meat dish over rice.  I recommend their Beef Chow Fun with black bean sauce, Salt & Pepper Pork Spareribs "over rice", and their shredded pork with eggplant.
author: Sheenie L.

description:
this place sucks! 

it ued to be sooooo gooood back then, but because they  changed chefs (thats what  i heard), it went downhill

bad service

bad service

bad service

baddddddddddddddd servicee...

foood no good

chili.. is quite good

but food? let me tell u.....its disgusting.

go try to find out for yourself.
author: jessica t.

description: Damn, they have really delicious red bean soup. Probably the best in the city.
author: O K.

description: Yum Yum! Despite previous reviews on poor service...This is actually the FIRST place with fun and awesome customer service.  You have got to check out "The Wizard" -- it's the waiter with these knock out eyebrows that reach out as far as The Great Wall!... One example is that we dropped a pair of chopsticks on the floor and before you know it, he has brought us a new pair (without even making eye contact or a peep for a new one!) Another example, is that The Wizard is ABC friendly and speaks more than do-able English to make picking that -oh-so-favorite-dish-but-don't-know-the-Chinese-name-for-it SUPER EASY to communicate in chinglish! So yep, good fun, good prices and yes, how could you pass up MARCO..... POLO... that is oh so conveniently right next door!
author: Karen C.

description: I used to come here when I was wee small and the owners were an old couple. Now, its run by a new set of staff and management kinda sucks. We got charged for taking home our leftovers. If you want a real good Chinese restaurant that doesn't use alot of tumeric or msg, try our Superior Palace on Balboa. It's a better bet.
author: Jason C. J.

description: Just sick of all these crappy chinese restaurants. Can't we get some decent food around here? I don't even know why this place is so popular. The food is extremely greasey and the waitresses seem like they're always having a bad day. You can just tell that they're talking about you from like a table away. HELLO. We know what you're saying. x_X Something always goes wrong.
author: Katherine C.

description: love the food, especially crispy chicken and mustard garlic.....nothing fussy, just food and fast service....no complaints so far
author: Zeyneb T.

description: Ok lemme try to remember the combo.  Beef Fried rice, the steak cubes, salt and pepper pork chops, shit, I cant remember the rest.  Anyways this place is pretty good.  I gotta ask someone what we usually order here.  Ill be back.
author: Hen A.

description:
a simple place, good food, great prices....that said, price  doesn't matter that much to me, just want to enjoy the food, and this place is just for that. the decor is simple, often crowded, kid friendly...love the oysters with black bean sauce, hot pots, the seafood in general. they have a happy hour, but i would suggest you pass. the happy hour food is real cheap, but not that great, order from the regular menu...infant son loves their congee, but i thought the fish chunks were too large for both baby and me. 

oh yes, and I think the style of food is Cantonese, so mild flavors, not for those who like spicy foods.
author: 和子

description: Very good crab, cheap prices, good quatlity, easy accomodations, what else do you need?
author: El Rey R.

description: The dishes here are soooo good! I came here for my bf's extended family for Chinese New Years dinner and it was delicious! They serve large dishes here. The lobster is cooked and chopped up so that the meat is easily taken out, the meat was perfectly juicy and tasty. Everything here was so tasty! I also like their walnut prawns, fish, beef and bok choy, ... there wasn't anything I didn't like here. I definitely recommend this place for large groups and good chinese!
author: Susan L.

description:
What you read below about this place is true folks.  Service is non-existent here and the portions they give you is anemic.    The food is average at best if not below par.   ANEMIC PORTIONS, NO SERVICE, AND OVER PRICE is what describes this place.  Shame on you for fooling me once but you won't fool me twice.  

AVOID THIS PLACE.
author: John S.

description: Nothing fancy here, just some yummy chinese food. Prices are decent so you can order alot, food is consistently good and always satifies my craving for restaurant chinese (MSG please). But like any chinese restaurant, 8 immortals has MSG on the spice rack and decor isnt the best. Take-out is a good bet
author: Ryan Y.

description: Do yourself a favor and don't expect a lot from this restaurant.  It's a local Chinese dive that will get the job done whether it's dine in or take out.  I've eaten here a couple of times with family when we were too lazy to find parking somewhere else, and while it's not fantastic or disgusting, it's consistently OK.  Which, if you think about it, is actually not a bad thing when you're in the hood and in the mood for some greasy/noodle/rice/meat.  Once you dig that, you're good to go.
author: Tony L.

description: Definitely cheap Chinese food served family style. Lots of seafood on the menu which is insanely cheap! Good eats!
author: Yan M.

description: Cheap... and good eats! Nothing fancy. No ambiance or decor. Just cheap, good, Chinese food (and fresh seafood!). This is where the Chinese people go for Chinese food when they don't want to cook (if you notice the lack of Chinese people dining at other Chinese restaurants, I wonder why?).
author: Zell C.

description: Good food, great prices, friendly staff. They also five you these tiny rice bowls so when you eat you refill it very often. When you can down 10 bowls of fried rice you feel kinda immortal?
author: Keit K.

description:
this is a cheap chinese place that goes slightly beyond the "acceptable cheap chinese food" standard.  i like the seafood dishes, especially the ones that involve a whole crab.  do yourself a favor and start your meal off with a quail.  it's small; you can handle a quail, your soup, and a whole bunch of seafood and tofu and taro root, too.  

this can be a good place to bring a fairly large party (around 8 people).  you often have to wait for a table, but usually the wait isn't too long.  the decor and service aren't anything special, but the food and prices are.  whenever i eat here i'm one of a handful of non-chinese people in the place; that makes me feel like i'm onto something.
author: Jeff W.

description: loving this place especially if you have a huge group, the food is good, its friggin cheap....the seafood here is fresh, and proportions are big.  Went here for MOthers day and we all had left overs. Went for friends Bday and had plenty of leftovers! i would so reccomend this place to anyone who love good fresh tasty chinese food.
author: Shirley H.

description: The food is pretty good and it's very very affordable. Try the salt and pepper crab, salt and pepper squid, and mandarin spare ribs. The place is kinda dirty and the food is a bit oily but hey can't complain for such a good and dirt cheap food.
author: Roy K.

description: Excellent place, tasty fresh food, and their $3.50 entree menu owns! Silly thing is that it's closed on Wednesdays, which for some unknown reason is the same day i always seem to want to go here!  Get there early or else you'll be waiting out the door or inbetween it!
author: ToAsTy T.

description: This place used to be excellent but the recent  visits had shown inconsistency on the same dishes that I used to order. The place is so busy all the time also because they have very good price. I like to come here also because Marco Polo next to it has excellent gelato!
author: Jen C.

description: Cheap and greasy.  This place would be great if you had biofuel car.  $20 gives you a meal for two and a ride home.  Definitely tell them less oil if you decide to go here.  This place was way better 10 years ago, but the chef must have changed.
author: Edmund W.

description: 4 stars for the food and prices...This is another one of those Sunset Specials. Dirt Cheap, yet great quality and good tasting food. They even have some pleasant, albeit overworked wait-people. The owner is always there at the register making sure things run smoothly. There even a second floor which we have not been privileged enough to dine in. Definitely no ambiance, no frills place. But they really have some great tasting food. Some of the food rivals the fancier Ton Kiang, RG Jounge, Koi Palace at half or a third of the price. Try their Fried Tofu with Shrimp and Salt and Pepper Spare Ribs.
author: B C.

description: I would have to say this is one of the best places for Chinese food in San Francisco! I give the food 5 stars!!! One of my family's favorite.  The food is fresh, tasty, and filling. I love the walnut shrimp, Pork spareribs, black bean fish, crab(when in season), and much more.  My mouth is watering just writing this review. The price is very inexpensive especially for large groups.  However, the service sucks! This place gets really crowded and the seating is very cramped.  Especially on Saturday nights. The servers are always busy, so they tend to ignore you. The wait is long too for a seating . So food 5stars and service 1minus one!
author: Leon C.

description: Popular restaurant with so-so food at a decent price.  Customer service is pretty bad.  They are not big on picking up their phone either.
author: L C.

description: I *love* this place!  It's become a ritual to stop here for luncheon at least once each time I visit SF.
author: Kai K.

description: Sometimes I go here for takeout at lunch, it's pretty quick and the food is alright. But, one time I brought my family to dinner at this place, everything was sticky and gross and the service was terrible, The food was late, the fish we ordered was completely burnt. Take-out should be fine, but you will regret dining.
author: Eric C.

description: Great food, fast service, good prices, not rushed.  Quantity could have been a bit more, but I'll take quality over a small difference in quantity any day.
author: M W W.

description: I like it. fresh seafood. cooked perfectly. a little crowded and loud but its expected from a really good chinese restaurant
author: derrick d.

description:
*i have another review after this, so take a peek..* =)

so, when my friend A, first suggested this place, i laughed at him and pointed to this restaurant, and said, "no way, we're going THERE?" there's actually a picture posted from another yelper.. chk it...

the yellow and red fortress looking building just wasn't doing it for me, but he insisted it was cheap and good. so, i gave in. how could you not? marco polo was right next door and i had to get me my gelato filling for the day...

Came here after church this past Sunday.. 

The food here was CHEAP!!! Now, that's 1 star.

The food didn't taste like no restaurant style, totally tasted homemade, which made it another star. Not to the point of MAJOR MSG.

-Diced chicken & salt fish fried rice $4
-Filet of Cod w/green veggie w/rice $4 that veggie was bok choy in case you were wondering.

Another star for huge portions and for filling me up SO good .. 1 star.

Great service (WOW, chinese restaurant having good service? that's the first* ... ) 1 star.

Food came out SUPER slow, seriously, SO slow, I thought I was going to doze off while waiting. -1star.

I'll come back soon!!! Xie xie!! Zhai zien~! =)
author: Jennifer S.

description: cheap GOOD eats in the set. you cant beat that. i think this place is where my love affair with chinese food started. i dated this cantonese girl that lived three blocks away from here. THANK GOD she introduced me. after all these years, i still find myself yearning for this joint. luckily its right next to my watering hole.
author: Euge L.

description:
Food is ok.  Not really tasty and not original.  Service has to be the worst I ever experienced.  I must have gone there 10x, but most of the time it was a group thing with lots of people.  On a few occasions, it was just me and someone else.  Seriously the worst when it is just two people. You are treated like they don't want you in there.

Once, me and my girlfriend went for lunch.  We waited for someone to come over to seat us for 15 minutes.  No one came over to even say hi or please wait, or have a seat or anything.  We left after that.  Two months later, we went again to try again.  Again we waited, but 10 minutes this time.  We got out menus and decided on what we want.  No one wanted to take out order.  We waited a good 30 minutes.  Waving someone down just did not work.  I joked with my girlfriend about how they are ignoring us.  Again we walked out.  We went to Szechuan Taste again.  Cheaper and better tasting.  I don't know why I even bothered.  And, it is like I never learn or something, I went again with my girlfriend.  It was like redemption or something.  This time we were seated in a timely matter and they took our order after flagging them down from across the restaurant (embarrassing).  I ordered something I forget what and a soup or something that had some fish balls or something.  It tasted like leftovers from last night.  It was not hot, it did not have much flavor.  It was just blah.  Hands down, worst Chinese restaurant in San Francisco.  

Quality: 2 stars
Taste: 0 stars
Service: 1 star
Price: 3 stars
Everything Else : one million stars as it does not matter since I can't go back anymore.
author: Christopher C.

description: I love getting their yee fu won ton! It's different From how other places make theirs. The other items are good especially the clay pot ones.
author: p a.

description: i agree with a few they dont really deserve a 3 nor a 4 and 3.5 would do it but i feel nice today so a 4 haha. im only comparing this place with other similar simple chinese restaurants cause i mean i gave broadway prime a 3 and i cant say this place is better cause theyre totally different dont get me wrong but anyways i used to attend the high school up the block so this was one of everyone's favorite good priced decent chinese joint. i'd usually order the salt n pepper spareribs :] yum i want some now! or maybe this scrambled raw egg & shrimp over rice which is so good. its kind of like comfort food a bit on the fatty side shouldnt be eaten all the time but do anyways cause its good for its price. most of the dishes over rice are about $5 and they fill you up so whats to complain?
author: melanie t.

description: it's where all the real chinese people eat at.  so you can expect 4 things, sketchy bathrooms, bad service, cheap prices, but really, really good food.
author: Alan N.

description: where else can you have a king's feast for $5 a person or less?? you could spend more on the dollar menu at mickey D's than you would here.. but here, you could get some oysters with black bean sauce, shrimp fried rice and other yummy seafood dishes.  the only thing holding this place back from a 5 star rating is the cleanliness, and service, but hey, what do you expect when you go to a chinese restaurant?
author: Waynele Y.

description:
some good, some yuk.
we went once, and we're not going back

wait staff was pretty friendly and helpful, the place was packed, so it looks like some people like it.  just not us.
author: Mom Of Three L.

description: Excellent food surprisingly cheap. Service is a little iffy but the price & quality of the food more than makes up for it.
author: sizuck m.

description: I've been eating there since I was a kid, almost 20 years! Their prices are awesome.  Restaurant is a bit small and cramped. Food is fresh and authentic. My favorites are the fried tofu with shrimp, Chinese broccoli with beef, and clams.
author: K C.

description: One of my favorite Chinese restaurants. I grew up eating at 8 immortals. I really love their peking spare ribs and their clams.
author: Michael H.

description: My husband and I stopped by this restaurant one late Saturday afternoon and were completely ignored.  We walked in and stood there forever, waiting to be seated and the hostess completely ignored us.  We then asked a waiter where we should sit and he said I needed to ask the hostess.  However, she kept walking back and forth, to the back of the restaurant and then back to her post and was completely rude and ignorant to us, even when I tried to get her attention and asked if we could be seated.    We're Caucasian and we truly felt that this was a case of racial prejudice.  After about 10 minutes, we turned around and left and we will NEVER come back here again.
author: olga d.

description: Went there last night for a New Years Eve Dinner, quite a mistake. First was the wait time, not too bad only a couple minutes, but the place was full. Then the wait for a waiter to take our order, 15 minutes, then for the foood 38 minutes, and one dish at a time, so we never all ate everything together. From the menu I wanted the individual meal for me, yet the waiter said it was too busy to do this meal for one person, so I just settled on fried rice, still 38 minutes to get an order of fried rice. Then we are finished eating and waiting for dessert, 20 minutes not even a waiter came by to ask us anything. When my wife finally saw a waiter and asked about the dessert he said ok, still nothing came. Then asked another waiter and she boldly said no sweet soup today, which was a lie since the people at another table just finished eating theirs. While the food my wife had was ok there was a serious porblem with this restaurant and the whole experience. I have eaten there many times, but for sure will never go back.
author: Dan H.

description: super cheap chinese food.  the taste tho, leaves a lot to be desired.  i wouldn't say it's bad, but i wouldn't say it's good either.
author: Dorothy L.

description: Among the three chinese restaurants clustered near each other on Taraval, this one is the best by far.  However, they raised their prices an average of 30% back in April/May (around then), so I dropped their rating a bit.  Before, they were an amazingly inexpensive restaurant with excellent food and I wondered how they survived as a business.  Now I don't frequent them as much because their portions are still small, and now they're expensive, relatively speaking.
author: A P.

description: This place is going down hill. I used to patronize this restaurant due to its reasonable prices and generous portions. However, my most recent visit was very disappointing. It appears that the prices have gone up significantly and the portions have shrunk. For example, I ordered a half chinese salt baked chicken....instead of use fresh chicken I could immediately tell that it was one of those chicken that was purchased from the local lucky's or safeway. The "half" chicken looks more like a quarter chicken. I suspect that they take out several portions of the chicken and use them in their other dishes. What a rip off. I can understand higher prices....but when I pay for half a chicken I want half a chicken!
author: D L.

description: There is afternoon tea here from 1- 5pm i believe. It's cheap! everything is 2 dollars and drinks are 1 dollar and it's not bad for that price. Regular food here is well priced. The food is worth its price, not horrible, but not fabulous.
author: vicky c.

description: Expect the WORSE restaurant service in Eight immortal restaurant.  First of all, the waitresses are very good in ignoring customer's requests.  Although the boss was always there, he is arrogant and unattentive.  At a recent visit, after we were seated, we had to wait over 20 mins for a high-chair for my 3 yr-old daughter.  No one came and serve tea for over 30 mins, and then when we were finally given a tea pot, there were no cups, and another time, plates w/o no forks.... and my mom actually had to grab utensils on her own so that we can start eating.  By the time we got everything, I've already filled up my stomach with anger and lost my appetite. I always knew that the boss is snobby and many people don't like this restaurant but I just had to experience it myself to believe it.  The ridiculously poor service made me decided not to ever give them business and it isn't a big loss since the food isn't exceptionally good anyway.
author: Annie L.

description: i may be biased a bit because my dad use to work at this restaurant, but not as a cook though. because of that, i've always had a fondness for this place since i was little. to sum it up, the food is not bad, but the only downside is that the portions are not that big. i absolutely love the inca cola's, not too sure which other places have these but they are awesome.
author: Vincent Y.
